Introduction1 Developments in exchange arrangements and exchange restrictions should be seen against the background of a sharp decline in the growth of world trade and a general widening of payments imbalances in the period under review. In volume terms, the growth of world trade fell to only 1V4 per cent in 1980, the lowest increase registered in five years and far below average rates of growth during the 1970s. Declining activity was responsible for a weakening of import demand in the indus tr ial countries. There was also a marked reduction in the growth of the volume of imports by the non-oil developing coun- tries, notwithstanding a substantial increase in external borrowing at higher costs and a considerable reduction in the real value of their international reserves arising mainly from rapid inflation. The growth of export volume of both the industrial coun- tries and the non-oil developing countries slowed, and although the growth of export earnings of both groups remained high in 1980, it lagged behind the increase in import costs, reflecting in part the impact of oil price increases in 1979 and 1980. The current account positions of a number of industrial and non-oil developing countries thus became increasingly difficult in 1980. The current account deficit of the industrial countries (exclusive of official t ran s fe r s ), which rose more than threefold over the previous year, included a very substantial increase for the smaller countries in this group. The current account of the seven ma jor industrial coun- tries as a group (exclusive of official transfers) can be expected to shift into surplus in 1981, largely because of the slack conditions likely to persist in some of these countries, but the deficit in the smaller industrial countries is likely to remain large. The combined current account deficit of the non-oil developing countries also increased substantially in 1980, to more than twice its size in 1978, and a fur ther sizable increase is in prospect for 1981. The deteriorating external position of the non-oil develop- ing countries in general, including the mounting costs of servicing the large additions to their external debt in recent years, has increased the pressure on many of these countries with liberal exchange and trade systems to adopt restrictive measures, and for those already applying restrictions, to in tens ify them. Compared to the conditions prevailing in the exchange markets of the major industrial coun- tries in most of 1979, exchange rate movements became more volatile in 1980 and early 1981. Despite increased intervention by central banks, and with greater variability of interest rates, the exchange rates among major currencies and currency blocs experienced periods of volatility. The size and speed of exchange rate variations, which were the result of rapidly shifting expectations among market partici- pants, sometimes appeared to be greater than changes in underlying conditions. The substantial variations of the exchange rates of the pound ster- ling, the Japanese yen, and the currencies participat- ing in the exchange rate and intervention mechanism of the European Monetary System (EMS )2 against the U.S. dollar at times exceeded relative current account and interest rate movements. Notwithstand- ing widening disparities in domestic price perfor- mances, the EMS continued to function relatively smoothly in its second year of operation, with occa- sionally substantial intervention in support of weak- ening currencies, transitory resort to its mechanisms of intervention finance, and one readjustment of central rates which resulted from the devaluation of the Ita- lian lira in March 1981. There were no changes with respect to participation in the EMS or its institutional arrangements during the period. While there were numerous downward adjust- ments in the external values of pegged currencies among the developing countries, that group as a whole experienced a fu r ther appreciation of real exchange rates. As detailed in Section II, many of the developing countries that pursued an active exchange rate policy are important exporters of manu fac tu res for which an adequately competitive exchange ra te is particularly significant. Possibly reflecting the increased uncer ta in ty and costs in terms of domestic policy ad jus tment associated with the increased fluctuations of the exchange rates among the major currencies during the period under review, there was a tendency for members to aban- don single currency pegs and to move toward the adoption of pegs on individualized currency baskets. Other developments in exchange regimes, not involv- ing a reclassification of exchange arrangements, included discrete changes in the exchange value of pegged currencies (mostly deva lua t ions ), changes in the mode or pace of change of preannounced exchange rates, ad jus tmen ts of currency baskets determining the exchange value of currencies (with- !This Report centers on exchange arrangements and exchange restrictions, but it also covers other external eco- nomic policy measures and intergovernmental arrangements that may have balance of payments implications. The period covered is 1980 and, where possible, the early part of 1981. 2 The currencies of Belgium, Denmark, France, Federal Republic of Germany, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, and Netherlands. 3 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS out necessarily involving a change in the level of the peg ), ad jus tmen ts of margins around the peg, the choice of a d i f fe rent intervention currency, the introduction of a new currency, and other changes in the institutional arrangements for determining exchange rates. Several, mostly South American, countries which attempted to use exchange rate policy to dampen inflationary expectations by pre- announcing f u t u re rates or to reduce inflation by appreciating their currencies in real terms reverted to other, more traditional exchange ra te policies. In an overall setting of excess capacity and rising unemployment, demands for protectionist measures in industrial countries intensified during the period under review. In certain sectors, the need for sub- stantive structural adjustment attained acute levels due to stiffening import competition and a renewed upsurge in energy costs. As reported in greater detail in Section III, the authorities in industrial countries have so far been successful in averting the adoption of generalized restrictions on foreign trade. On the other hand, the widespread weakening of economic activity, exacerbated in a few cases by emerging external payments pressures, has all but stalled progress in the endeavor to provide develop- ing countries more liberal access to the markets in the industrial countries. Actions to buttress the multilateral trad ing system included the adoption of a stronger and permanent Trade Pledge by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) ,3 selective improvements in national schemes of tariff prefer- ences to developing countries, and the provisional acceptances and official ratifications by a growing number of countries of the various agreements to lower tar iff and non ta r i ff barriers, as negotiated in the Tokyo Round of the Multilateral Trade Negoti- ations (MTN) under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tar iffs and Trade (GATT ) .4 The first round of the agreed tar iff reductions on manu- fac tu red products was ins t i tu ted in 1980, and the institutional framework for the implementation of the nontariff agreements became operational. As protectionist pressures intensified, in particular with respect to trade among industrial countries, demands 3 Australia, Aus t r ia, Belgium, Canada, Denma rk, Finland, France, Federal Republic of Germany, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, Netherlands, New Zea- land, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, United Kingdom, and United States. 4 The outcome of the Tokyo Round negotiations and the various agreements were described in the Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions, 1980, pages 6-7. 4 for restraint agreements and other protectionist measures have spilled over into new sectors, such as automobiles, electronic equipment, and petrochemi- cals. By early 1981, negotiated or unilateral limita- tions, supplemented in certain cases by antidumping or countervailing duties and subsidies for domestic production, constrained to varying degrees the trade in textiles and clothing, footwear, steel, ships, and certain consumer electronics. For the non-oil developing countries, the fu r ther intensification of payments d iff icu l t ies not only pre- cluded generalized progress toward liberalization of those countries' trade and payments systems but created pressures for some of them to adopt more restrictive external policies. As mentioned below, external payments arrears continued to occur in many of these countries, a point highlighted in last year's Report. In view of the overall circumstances of this group of countries, however, the avoidance of a significant increase in the use of restrictive measures, especially exchange restrictions (see Sec- tion III, be low ), is no tewo r thy and reflects, to an impor tant extent, the ability of the international capital markets to meet their financing needs, as well as the sharply increased financial assistance provided by the Fund in support of comprehensive adjust- ment programs. External payments arrears remained a serious problem in many countries throughout the period covered by this Report. While none of the countries reported as incurring payments arrears in 1979 is known to have eliminated them in 1980 and restored fu l ly a system of prompt paymen ts, the total of arrears outstanding on current and capital payments declined slightly to about SDR 5.3 billion at the end of 1980, represen t ing about 42 per cent of aggregate merchandise exports of the 26 countries concerned. This compares with ou ts tand ing arrears of about SDR 0.7 billion at the end of 1975, representing just under 10 per cent of 1975 exports of the 13 member countries incurr ing arrears at that time. Without the ref inanc ing or rescheduling of a substantial amount of debt service by official and commercial bank creditors of 3 of the countries, the arrears outstand- ing would have continued their upward trend in 1980, instead of registering a moderate decline. In view of its con t inu ing concern over the arrears prob- lem, the Fund conducted a comprehensive review of its policies and procedures on external payments arrears in late 1980 (see Section III.4, below). In other areas of restrictions, import controls were, on balance, tightened with the notable excep- tion of a few countries, predominantly in Asia and ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAIN DEVELOPMENTS IN EXCHANGE RATES AND EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS South America, that initiated or continued ma jor programs to remove or reduce quan t i ta t ive and cost restrictions on imports. On the other hand, revers- ing a development observed in last year's Report, members reduced their reliance on advance import deposit requirements. With respect to exports and export proceeds, subsidized export credits by OECD countries increased substantially. Comparatively few developing countries expanded financial incen- tives to exports. In par t icu lar, d i f f icu lt budge tary situations curtailed the scope for the extension of fiscal incentives. Such measures as were taken were generally tailored to the needs of particular sectors. However, reflecting the widespread balance of pay- ments d iff icu l t ies, there was a notable increase in the tightening of repatriation and surrender require- ments of exchange proceeds f rom exports and other transactions. As in other recent years, countries limiting access to foreign exchange for cu r rent invisi- bles generally increased their exchange allocations, but in the face of generalized price increases, such adjustments in many instances merely served to ma in ta in or re-establish the real value of allocations. Owing partly to the adoption of ad jus tment pro- grams supported by the Fund by a greater number of countries, progress was made du r ing the period under review toward the elimination of multiple currency practices. The number of member countries engaging in multiple currency practices fe ll from 40 in early 1980 to 36 in early 1981. In March 1981 the Fund concluded a comprehensive review of its policies and procedures on multiple currency practices, which led to the adoption of a mod if ied set of guidelines (see Section III.5 and the Annex, below). There was a fu r th er modera te dec l ine in the number of bilateral paymen ts arrangemen ts invo lv ing Fund member countries. Comparatively few measures were taken by indus- trial countries to a f fect capital flows in the period under review. Such measu res as were taken were generally intended to moderate trends in exchange rates and reserve movements. Apa rt from direct official borrowing f rom surplus countries, countries with weakening balance of paymen ts performance tended to remove the remaining controls on inflows and, in some instances, restricted certain outflows toward the end of 1980 and early 1981. As in the past, most of the control measures focused on flows through the banking system. As a result of the recent changes, the major industrial countries are now more open to capital inflows than at any time during the 1970s. Among developing countries, there were only a few fu r ther restrictions on capital ou tf lows. Capital f lows th rough the b a n k i ng system were liberalized by several South American coun- tries. However, as in recent years, most of the l ibera l iz ing measures sought to a t t r a ct cap i tal in the fo rm of d irect foreign inves tmen t. W i th the accession to membe rsh ip by Zimbabwe on September 29, 1980, to tal Fund membership increased to 141 countries. Main Developments in Exchange Rates and Exchange Arrangements Th is section repor ts on ma jor developments in members' exchange ra tes and exchange arrange- men ts as no t if ied to the Fund in accordance with members' obligations under Ar t ic le IV, Section 1, of the Articles of Agreemen t. Developments in respect of mu l t ip le ma rket a r rangemen ts and official measures re su l t ing in d i f f e r ent buy ing or selling rates are summa r ized in a separa te section on mu l t i- ple currency practices. There were no ma jor changes in the institutional a r rangemen ts of or pa r t ic ipa t ion in the EMS du r ing 1980 and early 1981. The Un i ted K ingdom, although forma l ly a member of the EMS, did not elect to p a r t i c ip a te in the exchange ra te and in ter- ven t ion mechan ism, and Italy con t inued to avail i tse lf of the option to m a in t a in, on a temporary basis, w ider fluctuation marg ins of 6 per cent. As a trans i- t ional a r rangemen t, following the d iscon t inua t ion of the one-for-one l ink between the Irish pound and the pound sterling, Ireland operated a mini-band within the ma in EMS band. The m in i-band was progres- sively widened in stages from initially 0.5 per cent un t il it reached the standard EMS band of 4.5 per cent (correspond ing to fluctuation margins of 2.25 per cen t) on June 13, 1980. Thereaf ter, the rate for the Irish pound w i th in the EMS band was determined by the ma rke t. Greece, which became a member of 5 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS the European Community (EC )5 on January 1, 1981 (see Section IV, below), did not, for the time being, participate in the exchange rate and intervention mechanism of the EMS. However, the Treaty of Accession provides that the drachma will be included in the basket of currencies comprising the European Currency Unit (ECU) during any revision of it which may be made before December 31, 1985. If no such revision takes place, December 31, 1985 is set as the latest date of the drachma's inclusion. In December 1980 the heads of state and govern- ment of the EC countries (the European Council) decided that the establishment of the European Monetary Fund (EMF), originally scheduled for no later than March 1981, should be postponed until an appropriate time and that, meanwhile, work should continue on the second, institutional stage of the EMS and on the gradual development of the use of the ECU. In this connection, it was decided to extend the interim arrangements of the EMS in their present form for a period of two years. Thus, the EC Council of Finance Ministers agreed to extend the Medium-Term Financial Assistance for two years from December 31, 1980, and the EC central bank governors decided to extend the present swap arrangements for a two-year period beyond the original expiration date of March 13, 1981. With effect from March 23, 1981 Italy devalued the lira by 6 per cent against the other currencies participating in the EMS. No other exchange rate adjustments were made during the period under review, but the system became subject to occasional strain and changes occurred in the relative positions of t}ie participating currencies. The Belgian franc breached its diver- gence threshold several times in February-March 1980 and again in February-March 1981, necessitat- ing intervention and tighter monetary measures.6 In 5 The other members are Belgium, Denmark, France, Federal Republic of Germany, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and United Kingdom. 6 Intervention in EMS currencies, which is required in unlimited amounts when bilateral limits are reached, may create claims or liabilities to the very short-term facility of the European Monetary Cooperation Fund (EMCF) which then normally must be settled by the transfer of ECUs or other reserve assets within 45 days of the end of the month in which intervention takes place. The divergence indicator is a measure of the divergence of the market rate expressed in ECU for each EMS currency f rom its ECU central rate. Divergence is permitted as far as the divergence thresholds, which are established for each currency, taking into account its weight in the ECU basket in such a manner that there is broadly the same degree of probability of each EMS cur- rency reaching its threshold. When a threshold is reached, there is a presumption that the authorities concerned will cor- 6 late 1980 and early 1981, the deutsche mark began to ease against other EMS currencies, eventually to the extent of occasionally replacing the Belgian franc at the bottom of the band; from time to time, sup- port for the deutsche mark was required against the French franc and the Netherlands guilder, which for certain periods were the strongest currencies in the system. In respect of credit mechanisms within the EMS, there was moderate resort to the Very Short- Term Financing Facility (VSTF) in order to support certain currencies —mainly the Belgian franc and, to a lesser extent, the deutsche mark. In the period under review, the U.S. dollar appre- ciated considerably against the EMS currencies and the Swiss f ranc but depreciated against the pound sterling and the Japanese yen. The U.S. dollar's per- formance was influenced to a large degree by the strengthening of the current account, and by interest rate movements. Following an initial strengthening due to rapidly rising domestic interest rates and the announcement of an anti-inflation program in March 1980, the U.S. dollar eased as interest rates on U.S. dollar-denominated assets fell sharply in April 1980. When interest rates on such assets began to rise again around mid-1980, the U.S. dollar resumed its firm- ing against most major currencies, with the exception of the pound sterling and the Japanese yen. In nomi- nal end-of-year terms, the EMS currencies and the Swiss f ranc depreciated against the U.S. dollar by between 10.5 per cent and 13.6 per cent during 1980, while the pound sterling and the Japanese yen appreciated by 7.2 per cent and 18.1 per cent, respectively. In the first quarter of 1981, the U.S. dollar appreciated against all the afore-mentioned currencies by between 4.0 per cent (against the Japanese yen) and 13.3 per cent (against the Italian l i ra ). As in 1978, but in contrast to 1979, there were sizable movements in the effective exchange rates 7 of most of the currencies of the industrial countries rect the situation by diversified intervention, measures of domestic monetary policy, changes in central rates, or other economic policy measures. 7 Based on the Fund's multilateral exchange rate model (M ERM ), in which the implicit weighting structure takes account of the relative importance of a country's trading par tners in its direct bilateral relationships with them, of competitive relationships with "third countries" in particular markets, and of estimated elasticities affecting trade flows. Changes in effective exchange rates derived from MERM may d i f fer from estimated effective exchange rate changes based on changes in trade-weighted exchange rate indices for which the relative importance of the exchange rate changes of particular countries is measured in terms of these coun- tries' shares in bilateral trade of the country in question. ©International Monetary Fund. In effective end-of-year terms, the largest appreciations in 1980 were recorded for the Jap- anese yen, the pound sterling, and the Australian dollar, which rose by 23.2 per cent, 12.0 per cent, and 9.8 per cent, respectively. The U.S. dollar gained 2.0 per cent in effective terms, while the Canadian dollar, the Norwegian krone, and the Swedish krona eased by between 1.1 per cent and 2.4 per cent. On the other hand, the EMS currencies, the Austrian schilling, and the Swiss f ranc depreci- ated by between 4.5 per cent and 9.5 per cent. Dur- ing the first quar ter of 1981, changes in effective rates included a strong appreciation of the U.S. dollar by 5.3 per cent and depreciations of the deutsche mark (1.0 per cen t ), the French franc (3.6 per cen t ), the Japanese yen (0.3 per cen t ), the pound sterling (0.7 per c en t ), and the Swiss franc (3.1 per cen t ). During the period under review, six members notified changes in exchange arrangements involving reclassification under the Fund's classification scheme for exchange arrangements (Table 1). In addition, initial notifications were received from the People's Republic of China and from Zimbabwe. The general trend of the notifications was away f rom single cur- rency pegs and toward individualized basket pegs. Iran decided in May 1980 to peg the rial directly to the SDR and determine the exchange rates of individual currencies daily on the basis of the SDR- rial peg and the rates for each currency in terms of the SDR as declared by the Fund. Previously, the Iranian rial had also been pegged to the SDR, but its exchange rate had been maintained within a target zone above and below the fixed central ra te; these target zones were based on the relative purchasing power of the rial vis-a-vis that of the currencies of Iran's major trading partners and other basic under- lying economic conditions. Three members announced exchange arrange- ments involving a peg to a currency composite other than the SDR. Botswana, which previously pegged its currency to the U.S. dollar, began in June 1980 to peg the pula to a basket of currencies consisting of the South African rand and the SDR. In August 1980 the People's Republic of China notified the Fund that the exchange rate of its currency, the renminbi, is determined on the basis of the value of a basket of internationally traded currencies, weighted with reference to their importance in China's external transactions and trends in their relative values. Exchange rates are calculated for a number of specified currencies on a daily basis, and new rates are published whenever the calculated rate deviates f rom the previously published rate by l/2 per cent for the currencies used frequently in China's external transactions or by 1 per cent for other currencies. Zimbabwe notified the Fund in October 1980 that the Zimbabwe dollar was linked to a basket of currencies weighted according to the currencies used in settlements. The currency weights in the basket are reviewed from time to time as settlement patterns emerge. In August 1980 Peru joined the group of member countries ad jus t ing their exchange rates according to a set of indicators. It discontinued the practice of advance announcement of the exchange rate of the sol in terms of the U.S. dollar and adopted a system under which the sol is depreciated f requen t ly in line with relative price movements between Peru and its ma jor trading partners. The particular fea tu res of the new exchange arrangements announced by the remaining three members led to their reclassification in the residual category "Other". Costa Rica informed the Fund in December that the dual exchange market established in September 1980 had been unified and that, as a temporary exchange arrangement, the colon had been allowed to float. All transactions, with the exception of external debt service payments of the Central Government, certain other previously approved private current invisibles, and other cen- tral government payments abroad, would be negoti- ated at the free market ra te; until the end of 1981, exempted payments would be made at the previous official selling rate.8 In February 1980 Korea ceased to peg the won to the U.S. dollar and began to deter- mine the exchange rate of the won on the basis of a currency basket composed of the SDR and a trade- weighted composite of currencies representing Korea's main trading partners. However, other factors would also be taken into account, if neces- sary, in establishing the rate of the won. Finally, Morocco adopted a flexible exchange arrangement beginning in September 1980. At that time, the authorities also changed the composition and weights of the currencies included in the basket used to determine the exchange ra te of the dirham to reflect both the trade pattern and the currencies used in settlement. Not for Redistribution MAIN DEVELOPMENTS IN EXCHANGE RATES AND EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS Numerous modifications of exchange arrange- ments which did not entail a change in the Fund's classification of the arrangements concerned were also notified to the Fund during the period under review. Such modifications can be broadly grouped into discrete adjustments in the exchange value of pegged currencies, changes in the mode or pace of change of preannounced exchange rates, adjustments of currency baskets determining the exchange value of currencies (without necessarily involving a change in the level of the peg ), adjustments of margins around the peg, the choice of a d ifferent intervention currency, the introduction of new currencies, and changes in the institutional arrangements for deter- mining exchange rates. A large number of members lowered the external value of their currency. While in most instances devaluations were sizable and reflected the need to correct appreciations in real terms that had taken place over a number of years, some countries devalued their currencies more frequently without, however, being guided by an explicit set of indi- cators. This included a small number of countries which preannounced their exchange rates so as to reduce uncertainty and to affect inflationary expec- tations. Bangladesh devalued the middle rate of the taka in terms of the pound sterling, the inter- vention currency, on three occasions in July and October (twice) 1980 by a cumulative total of 10.8 per cent. In February and March 1981, however, the taka's middle rate in terms of the pound sterling was adjusted twice, resulting in an appreciation of 3.6 per cent vis-a-vis that currency but a deprecia- tion in terms of the SDR and the U.S. dollar of 1.3 percent and 3.5 per cent, respectively. In June 1980 Equatorial Guinea devalued its currency by 50 per cent against the Spanish peseta, to which it is pegged. Kenya, whose currency is pegged to the SDR, reduced the value of the shilling against the SDR by 4.8 per cent in February 1981. In January 1980 Korea devalued the won by 16.6 per cent against the U.S. dollar, to which the won was pegged before the adoption of an individualized basket in February 1980. Also in January 1980 the Lao People's Dem- ocratic Republic changed the official exchange rate for the kip from KN 4 per US$1 to KN 10 per US$1. At the start of 1981 Romania implemented a set of measures which amounted to a devaluation, on average, of the leu for trade and trade-related trans- actions. While the nominal exchange rate for such transactions was revalued from lei 18 per US$1 to lei 15 per US$1, the system of equalization payments which were designed to make the leu value of all exports and the leu cost of some imports equal to the domestic leu value of the goods concerned was terminated.10 The Solomon Islands informed the Fund that in March 1981 the exchange value of the Solomon Islands dollar was reduced by about 6 per cent in terms of its intervention currency, the Aus- tralian dollar, to SI$1 = $A 1; this change brought the exchange value of the Solomon Islands dollar back to the level prevailing before the May 1979 revaluation. In Janua ry 1980 Turkey devalued the lira by 33 per cent in terms of the U.S. dollar for most transactions while establishing a preferential exchange rate for imports of fertilizer and insecti- cides as well as for inputs for their domestic produc- tion (see Section III.5, below). During the remainder of 1980, the Turkish lira was devalued seven more times vis-a-vis the U.S. dollar for a total depreciation of the basic rate of 60.8 per cent in 1980. In the first quarter of 1981 the value of the Turkish lira vis-a-vis the U.S. dollar was adjusted three times, resulting in a cumulative depreciation of 6.7 per cent. Viet Nam, whose currency is pegged to the SDR, devalued the dong by 13.2 per cent in November 1980. Yugoslavia, which until Febru- ary 1981 maintained a fluctuating exchange rate, depreciated the dinar by 23.1 per cent on June 7, 1980; in 1980 as a whole, the middle rate of the dinar vis-&-vis the U.S. dollar depreciated by 34.6 per cent. Within the context of stabilization pro- grams supported by the Fund, Zaire devalued the zaire against the SDR by 30 per cent in February 1980 and by 40 per cent in June 1981. India, which maintains the value of its currency within 5 per cent of a weighted basket of currencies of its ma jor trading partners, frequently changed the exchange rate of the rupee against its intervention currency, the pound sterling, for a cumulative depre- ciation of 5.6 per cent during 1980. Countries which frequently changed the exchange rate of their cur- rency without following strictly an explicit set of indicators and their cumulative rates of change in 1980 against their intervention currency, the U.S. dollar, were Iceland (a depreciation of 36.7 per cen t ), Korea (a depreciation of 26.7 per cen t), and New Zealand (an appreciation of 2.5 per cen t ). In addition, Brazil, Colombia, Portugal, and, since August 1980, Peru adjusted their exchange rates 10 In late January 1981 Romania lowered the premium applied to the official rate of lei 4.47 per US$1 with respect to purchases and sales of currencies from nonsocialist coun- tries and Yugoslavia for nontrade transactions, with the result that the rate for such transactions became lei 11 per US$1 instead of lei 12 per US$1 previously. 9 ©International Monetary Fund. The cumulative rates of devaluation against the U.S. dollar of the currencies of the afore- mentioned countries during 1980 were 35.1 per cent, 13.6 per cent, 6.1 per cent, and 26.8 per cent, respec- tively. In the case of Peru, this total includes pre- announced end-of-month exchange rates until July 1980, when Peru ceased to preannounce its exchange rate three months in advance. Chile, which had abandoned in mid-1979 the advance announcement of its exchange rate in favor of a fixed rate of the peso vis-a-vis the U.S. dollar until February 1980, announced in January 1980 that the fixed rate would be maintained indefinitely. A few modifications were adopted by the coun- tries relying on advance announcement of their exchange rates. Argentina ceased at the start of 1980 to adjust the exchange rate of the peso in accordance with preannounced schedules of daily buying rates. Instead, the peso was to be devalued by 2.8 per cent in January 1980, to be followed by adjustments that would be 0.2 percentage points smaller each month, a procedure which would have resulted in exchange rate stability after March 1981. In September 1980, however, Argentina decided, in light of a strong real appreciation of the peso, to avoid any fu r ther deceleration of the monthly rate of devaluation by applying the rate of devaluation of 1 per cent originally scheduled for October also to November and the following months. In December this arrangement was confirmed for the spot buying rate, while the spot selling rate was to be increased by 2 per cent each month during the first three months of 1981. The Central Bank would sell foreign exchange if the announced selling rate is reached, and it would buy or sell foreign exchange if the announced buying rate or selling rate, respectively, is reached. In February 1981 the peso was devalued by 9.1 per cent vis-a-vis the U.S. dollar, and the spot selling and buying regulation rates were adjusted accordingly. At the same time, Argentina reverted to announcing daily rates by publishing a schedule of regulation rates through the end of August 1981. According to the schedule, the selling rate increases by 3 per cent a month during the period and the buying rate rises by 2 per cent a month during February-March 1981 and by 3 per cent a month for the remainder of the period. Following a two-day closure of the exchange market, the spot buying and selling rates of the peso were depreciated by 24.5 per cent and 23.2 per cent, respectively, on April 2, 1981; moreover, it was announced that the exchange rate of the peso would be adjusted by small amounts at frequent intervals 10 and that the Central Bank would determine the spot buying and selling regulation rates for the U.S. dollar. On June 2, 1981 the spot buying and selling rates of the peso were depreciated by about 23 per cent, and it was announced that the Argentine peso would be fur ther depreciated by about 6 per cent in the course of June. Brazil, which is classified as ad jus t ing its currency according to a set of indicators, announced devaluation targets for 1980 as a whole and for the period July 1980- June 1981. In November 1980, however, the Bra- zilian authorities announced that they would discon- tinue, f rom the beginning of 1981, the practice of announcing devaluation targets. Portugal, also classified as ad jus t ing its currency according to a set of indicators, lowered the preannounced monthly rate of depreciation of the escudo in effec t ive terms f rom 0.75 per cent to 0.5 per cent in July 1980. Uruguay announced in May 1980 that the new peso would be depreciated by 15 per cent in the course of 1980. At the end of 1980 the target rate of depreciation during the first five months of 1981 was set at 6.48 per cent. In the meantime, in September 1980, a new schedule of daily buying and selling rates for Janua ry and February 1981 had been pub- lished, which implied a 2.8 per cent devaluation against the U.S. dollar for that period. In the first quar ter of 1981, monthly schedules until the end of September 1981 were published, indicating a cumu- lative depreciation of the new peso against the U.S. dollar of 11.4 per cent during the first nine months of 1981. Revaluations, which occurred less frequen t ly than devaluations, involved generally small adjustments in the external value of the currencies concerned. Botswana revalued the pula by about 5.3 per cent against its currency basket in November 1980. In March 1980 Finland revalued the markka by 2 per cent within the posted fluctuation limits, to reflect the average change in the exchange rate of the cur- rencies most important for Finland's foreign trade. Also in March 1980, a revision of Malta's currency basket resulted in a minor appreciation of the Malta pound both against the U.S. dollar and in effective terms. In early April the continued strength of the U.S. dollar triggered a new ad jus tment in the basket formu la which resulted in a 4.3 per cent apprecia- tion of the Malta pound against the U.S. dollar. As the maintenance of the new basket would have resulted in a fu r ther appreciation of 6 per cent by late April, the Maltese authorities reverted to the basket introduced in March 1980, which limited the additional appreciation against the U.S. dollar to ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAIN DEVELOPMENTS IN RESTRICTIVE PRACTICES 1.5 per cent. In March 1981, following the devalua- tion of the Italian lira, that currency was removed from the basket, and its weight was allotted to the U.S. dollar and the Japanese yen. This adjustment resulted in a 0.5 per cent appreciation of the Malta pound vis-a-vis the currencies in the basket. While continuing its policy of depreciating the escudo by small amounts each month against a basket of cur- rencies, Portugal revalued the escudo by 6 per cent in effective terms in February 1980. In the same month Nepal, which maintains a dual market for the U.S. dollar, raised its second official exchange rate by 14.3 per cent against the U.S. dollar while simultaneously reducing the coverage of transactions through the basic market. In August Nepal appreci- ated the buying rate for banknotes by 2.6 per cent in the case of the U.S. dollar and by 1 per cent in the case of other major currencies. In the course of 1980 and early 1981, the currencies of Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates were adjusted upward in terms of the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency. Although pegged to the SDR, the three countries maintain margins not exceeding 7.25 per cent around their pegs. As part of a package of measures to combat inflation, Seychelles revalued its exchange rate in terms of the SDR by 15 per cent in March 1981. Four members adjusted the currency baskets on which their exchange rates are based. Cape Verde reduced the number of currencies composing its basket from 11 to 9 in January 1980. As mentioned previously, in March 1980 Malta initially revised its basket in order to take into account the flow of trade in 1979 as well as the past and prospective cost of oil imports. The subsequent changes, including the removal of the Italian lira in March 1981, were aimed at steering a middle course between strong and weak currencies. When devaluing the Solomon Islands dollar in March 1981, the Solomon Islands changed the weights of the 4 currencies in the basket to which the Solomon Islands dollar is pegged, to reflect settlement rather than trade patterns. In accordance with recent practice, Sweden updated in April 1980 the weights of its currency basket to take account of average shares on the basis of trade statistics for the last five calendar years. Two countries which do not maintain the exchange rate of their currency within announced margins notified the Fund that they were using currency baskets to guide them in the setting of exchange rates. In February 1981 Iceland began to let the rate of the krona follow the trade and payments- weighted average of exchange rates. The Icelandic authorities consider this temporary practice, which was adopted mainly because of the unsettled exchange rate situation in early 1981, as one of several guidelines for the conduct of exchange rate policy. Also in February 1981, Yugoslavia per- mitted the exchange rate of the dinar to fluctuate within margins of 8 per cent around a basket of 11 currencies representing the relative importance of those currencies in Yugoslavia's total payments. Within the band, the exchange rate of the dinar is determined in accordance with certain indicators, such as relative producer prices and Yugoslavia's current account position. Two countries, whose currencies are pegged to country-specific currency baskets, adjusted the mar- gins around the peg. Bangladesh raised the margins for fluctuations of the effective exchange rate of the taka in January 1980 from plus or minus 2.5 per cent to plus or minus 3.5 per cent. However, together with the devaluation of the taka in terms of the pound sterling in October 1980, the margins were reduced to plus or minus 1 per cent. In Janu- ary 1980 Finland reduced the upper and lower fluctuation limits of its currency index from 121 and 114 to 119 and 112, respectively. The previously mentioned revaluation of the markka in March 1980 was effected within the new fluctuation limits. There was only one change in intervention cur- rency notified during the review period when Papua New Guinea replaced the Australian dollar with the U.S. dollar for this purpose in April 1980. New currencies' were introduced by four members. In March 1981 Equatorial Guinea replaced the ekuele by a new currency, the epkwele, at the rate of one to one. At the start of 1981 Iceland issued a new monetary unit. Although the official name, the krona, was retained for the new unit, its value is one hundred times that of the old one. The new krona is divided into 100 aurar. Old notes and coins were to remain legal tender until mid-1981, but the Cen- tral Bank was prepared to exchange new currency for old un t il the end of 1982. In February 1980 Israel introduced a new national currency, the shekel, equivalent to ten times the Israel pound, which it is to replace after a transitional period during which both currencies will circulate with each other. Finally, Lesotho began issuing a national currency, the maloti, in January 1980. The maloti is pegged at par to the South African rand, which continues to be legal tender. III. Main Developments in Restrictive Practices 1. Imports and Import Payments a. Quantitative Import Controls Despite a marked increase in protectionist pres- 11 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS sures originating from falling demand, excess capac- ity, and import competition, the industrial countries avoided recourse to comprehensive controls on imports during the review period. Resistance to such pressures was facilitated by a commitment by national governments to an open trading system, as manifested by the decision of the OECD countries in June 1980 to replace the annual trade pledges under- taken since 1974 with a permanent and more com- prehensive Trade Pledge. Also, agreements reached in the Tokyo Round of the MTN generally strength- ened the framework for the conduct of international trade. Nevertheless, trade-restrictive measures once again tended to be applied selectively to certain coun- tries and sectors. At the level of certain indus- tries considered impor tant in terms of employment or national security, existing restrictions were main- tained or intensified, such as for footwear, textiles, and steel, while pressures emerged for extending con- trols to other sectors, such as electronic equipment, petrochemicals, and automobiles. In contrast to pre- vious years, new protectionist pressures arose in trade among industrial countries. The decision by the EC to subject Japanese exports of automobiles, color tele- vision sets and tubes, and certain mach ine tools to statistical ex post surveillance beginning in March 1981 is a case in point. These developments in industrial countries contributed to a slowing expan- sion of world trade which, along with the sharp growth of energy import bills, brought about balance of paymen ts pressures in many non-oil developing countries, which, on balance, increased the ir recourse to quan t i ta t ive import restrictions. International trade in textiles and clothing con- tinued to be regulated by the second Multifiber Arrangement (MFA) negotiated under the auspices of the GATT, which covers the period 1978-81. There were no ma jor changes in the operation of most bilateral restraint agreements, which had been negotiated for multi-year periods generally ending in 1981 or 1982 within the framework of the MFA between the principal industrial importing countries and exporting developing countries. Eight new bilateral agreements under Article 4 of the MFA, which permits the imposition of restrictions for the purpose of eliminating the risk of market disruptions, 11 The agreements were concluded between the following pairs of countries or territories: Austria and Hong Kong, Canada and India, Canada and Malaysia, Finland and India, Finland and Korea, Sweden and Yugoslavia, United States and Malaysia, and United States and Sri Lanka. 12 were notified by signatories to the Textile Surveil- lance Body between January-September 1980.11 In addition, the United States negotiated new bilateral agreements with two nonsignatories.12 Also with respect to textiles, the Benelux countries and Thailand signed an agreement on ju te yarn incorporating export restraint provisions. In March 1980 the EC replaced quan t i ta t ive restrictions on ju te fabr ics f rom Bangladesh and India with volun- tary export res t ra int agreements with the two coun- tries covering the period 1981-83. France subjected imports of velvets and fu rs to a new administrative control system and required strict labeling of imported textiles as to the country of origin. Finland extended m in imum import prices for certain clothing items th rough 1980. Ireland introduced surveillance of impor ts for clothing of non-EC origin. No rway extended its global quotas on textile imports through the end of 1981. Spain imposed quotas on synthetic fibers f rom France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Italy, the United Kingdom, and the United States. Under au tho r i ty from the Commission of the EC, the United Kingdom in February 1980 imposed import quotas on two types of synthetic fibers from countries other than members of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA),13 preferen t ial countries, or countries w i th which the EC ma in ta ined bilateral agreements under the MFA. The measure, which a f fec ted primarily U.S. exports, was withdrawn at the end of 1980. In contrast to the generally restric- tive trend, New Zealand removed or reduced pro- tective measures on a number of textile products. Imports of steel remained subject to controls in ma jor indus t r ial countries. Modifications and a few new restrictions were introduced by the EC, the Un i ted States, and some other countries. The EC raised its basic reference prices 14 governing imports from nonmember countries in 1980 by between 2 per cent and 5 per cent over 1979 levels for ordinary steel and by about 16 per cent for special alloy steels. In October 1980 the deteriorating per- formance of the EC steel industry led to the imposition, for the first time since the formation of the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) in 1952, of com- pulsory production cutbacks within the EC. As mandatory quarterly production quotas for EC steel producers in the first half of 1981 were set at about 20 per cent below production in the same period in 1980, corresponding cutbacks on imports will be negotiated for 1981 with supplier countries with which agreements were concluded for 1980. In addition, the EC is negotiating new agreements with other coun- tries, such as Korea and certain East European coun- tries, whose exports were not restrained in 1980. The United States reinstated in October 1980 a modified trigger price mechanism for steel imports which featured a new "surge" mechanism.16 Under the original trigger price mechanism, which had been in effect since February 1978 un t il its suspension in March 1980, steel imports whose prices fell below periodically adjusted price floors au toma t ica l ly trig- gered an antidumping investigation. Trigger prices were raised by 12 per cent on average in October 1980 compared w i th March 1980; they were subse- quently increased by another 0.9 per cent in the first quar ter of 1981 and by 4.4 per cent in the second quarter. In other measures affec t ing trade in steel, the United States phased out quotas on specialty steel products in February 1980. However, specialty steel was placed under an import monitor- ing program similar to the "surge" mechanism of the trigger price mechanism in Janua ry 1981. Among other countries, Aus tra l ia and Mexico tightened quantitative controls on certain steel products. Restrictions on the import of selected other items were introduced by several indus t r ial countries. Australia slightly reduced the quotas on passenger automobiles and in troduced quotas on certain u t i l i ty vehicles. Spain suspended its liberalization of cheese imports, and the United K ingdom prohibited the impo r ta t ion of new potatoes f rom Spain and Greece. The Un i ted States also prohibited all imports f rom Iran in April 1980 and in November 1980 imposed an embargo on tuna impor ts from Ecuador. Japan continued to make s ign if icant progress in d isman t l ing ma rket barriers. It also reached an agree- ment with Canada in June 1980 to reduce quantita- tive restrictions on imports of cer ta in leather items which had been in e f fect since 1952. Among other indus t r ial countries, import licensing systems were relaxed in Finland and New Zealand. A number of developing countries relaxed their import regimes. Where such liberalizations were subs tan t ia l, they tended to be taken in conjunction w i th ma jor ad ju s tment programs which were sup- ported by use of the Fund's resources. In December, Pakistan removed licensing ceilings on all permitted imports, except for consumer goods and synthetic yarn, and added more than 120 basic raw materials 13 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS to the lists of permitted imports. Peru accelerated and completed in September 1980 the process of freeing its import system. Following substantial liberalization in late 1979 and especially in 1980, almost all imports may now be made freely. The Phil- ippines added a large number of items to the list of freely importable commodities and relaxed approval controls on imports of aircraft and cocoa. Sri Lanka also made headway in reducing its list of imports subject to prior approval, while Venezuela removed the licensing requirement for a large number of imports. Import restrictions on specific products were lifted or relaxed by a number of other develop- ing countries, often for reasons other than the respective countries' overall payments position. The countries included Argentina, Bolivia, Ecuador, Fiji, India, Indonesia, Korea, Morocco, Nepal, Papua New Guinea, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Africa, Thailand, Turkey, Uruguay, and Yugoslavia. Egypt disinvoked GATT Article XXXV with respect to Portugal. As a result, Egypt restored the application of the GATT agreement in its trade with Portugal. The generally difficult balance of payments situa- tion for developing countries caused many of them to tighten quantitative import controls. Comprehen- sive licensing requirements for imports were intro- duced in Malta and Sierra Leone. Licensing on certain categories of imports was introduced in Fiji, Mexico, and Seychelles, while prior authorization for certain imports was imposed in Ecuador, Mauritania, Senegal, and the Yemen Arab Republic. Mauritania also established quotas for several imports while sus- pending the imports of many other products, some of which could be produced domestically. Bolivia prohibited the importation of a variety of manufac- tured products. Iran imposed <a ban on luxury imports. Imports of passenger automobiles and certain other motor vehicles and parts became sub- ject to quotas or outright bans in many developing countries. Costa Rica, Ecuador, Ghana, the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya, Niger, and Western Samoa pro- hibited imports of certain motor vehicles, while Barbados and Mauritania subjected them to quotas. Grenada required prior authorization for the impor- tation of any motor vehicle with an engine capacity exceeding 1,600 cubic centimeters. Other countries which tightened quantitive import restrictions on other products included India, Indonesia, Ivory Coast, and Nepal. Many countries lifted restrictions on transactions with Zimbabwe (formerly Rhodesia) in 1980 and early 1981 in line with a United Nations Security Council resolution of October 1979 to that effect. 14 b. Import Surcharges and Import Taxation There were relatively few major trade actions relating directly to the use of import surcharges during the period under review. Following a reduc- tion from 12.5 per cent to 7.5 per cent in 1979, the common import surcharge in Botswana, Lesotho, South Africa, and Swaziland was eliminated in March 1980. Peru abolished a 10 per cent surcharge on food items, which had been in effect since May 1978, and eliminated a 1 per cent surcharge on a large number of customs items. In an effort to cushion the impact of the removal of quantitative restrictions, Peru also applied temporary surcharges of 10 per cent and 20 per cent ad valorem on the import of certain finished textiles and clothing items as well as electrical appliances. These surcharges were introduced in January and February 1980 and withdrawn in May and October 1980, respectively. Turkey reduced the stamp duty on imports from a maximum of 25 per cent to 1 per cent for all imports except luxury goods, which remained subject to a 100 per cent stamp duty. Special import fees or duties in the form of surcharges were introduced or raised in other countries. Cyprus increased the sur- charge on all imports to 3.5 per cent, except for certain essential and public sector imports. In Sep- tember 1980 Liberia introduced surcharges of 25 per cent on luxury goods and 15 per cent on most other impor ts; it also imposed import fees of 7.5 per cent on duty-free and transshipment goods, 5 per cent on duty-paid goods (excluding essential goods), and 1.5 per cent on duty-paid essential goods. Mauritius raised the import fee to 5 per cent from 2 per cent and imposed a 10 per cent surcharge on all imports. Thailand introduced temporary sur- charges ranging from 10 per cent to 50 per cent on a variety of imports. Other developing countries which introduced or raised surcharges were Costa Rica, St. Lucia, and Sierra Leone. In the case of Costa Rica, however, all surcharges were subse- quently reduced to a uniform level of 1 per cent. Tariff reductions negotiated in the Tokyo Round of the MTN began to be implemented at the start of 1980 by most of the countries that have accepted the Geneva Protocol of 1979 and the Supplementary Protocol.17 In the case of the nine major industrial 17 By the end of 1980, the following 23 countries had fu l ly accepted the Geneva Protocol: Argentina, Austria, Czechoslovakia, EC countries except Belgium (i.e., Den- mark, France, Federal Republic of Germany, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and United K ingdom ), Finland, Hungary, Iceland, Jamaica, Japan, New Zealand, Norway, Romania, South Africa, Sweden, Switzerland, and United ©International Monetary Fund. In addition to the tariff actions related to the Tokyo Round, several industrial countries implemented further tariff liberalization measures during the period under review. Australia reduced tar iffs on a variety of manufactured products and abolished duties on certain Pharmaceuticals. Following dis- cussions with the United States on trade in automo- biles, Japan decided to eliminate duties on most automotive parts in April 1981. Spain extended through January 1982 the substantial temporary reductions in both ad valorem and specific import duties introduced in April 1979. The United States reduced the specific duty on sugar imports in Febru- ary 1980 in response to rising sugar prices in the world market. Tariff reductions also resulted from agreements reached by EFTA with Spain and Ice- land. The Generalized System of Preferences (GSP ), under which industrial countries provide tariff prefer- ences for imports from developing countries, con- tinued to operate during the period under review with relatively few changes. In January 1981 the EC introduced a new GSP scheme for a period of ten years. The most significant change in the new scheme was the application of preferences on a "differential" basis, thereby shifting preferences for most products from global quotas as in the past to ceilings for individual supplier countries. The size of country quotas is lower the more developed a beneficiary country is; criteria for determining the level of development include per capita gross national product and the share in EC imports of particular products. However, imports from the least developed of the developing countries were not subject to any quota limitations. The EC also added a few additional industrial and agricultural products to its GSP list. Japan modified its GSP scheme in April 1980 and introduced special treatment for the least developed of the developing countries by grant- ing duty-free access for most GSP products from such countries without ceiling limitations. In addi- tion, Japan reduced the GSP tariff rate for three food and beverage items. The United States amended its GSP scheme in March 1980 by waiving the requirement to withdraw the duty exemption for beneficiaries accounting for more than half of total States. The following 17 countries had fu l ly accepted the Supplementary Protocol: Australia, Dominican Republic, Egypt, EC countries (except Be lg ium), India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Peru, Singapore, and Uruguay. U.S. imports of a product on the GSP list, if total U.S. imports of that product during 1979 were less than US$1 million (de minimis provision). Also in March 1980, the United States added 50 items to the list of goods covered by its GSP scheme. During the period under review, the People's Republic of China and Zimbabwe became designated as GSP beneficiaries in most industrial countries. The United States granted most-favored-nation (MFN) status to the People's Republic of China in January 1980. However, a number of countries eliminated preferential tariff treatments. For exam- ple, Australia announced the termination of all remaining preferential tar iffs on imports from the United Kingdom effective July 1981. Canada with- drew preferential tariff treatment for South Africa. It also decided to phase out preferential tar iffs for Ireland and the United Kingdom by Janua ry 1982 and replaced them with post-MTN MFN rates. South Africa also abolished preferential tar iffs for Commonwealth imports. Several developing countries eased their import t a r i f fs during the period under review. In a few cases, the measures were part of comprehensive programs aiming at the rationalization and reduc- tion of protective systems. The People's Republic of China eliminated duties on some food imports and reduced duties on many other products. Pro- ceeding with its tariff reform initiated in late 1979, Peru made numerous adjustments in individual tariff rates, mostly in a downward direction, which culmi- nated in September 1980 in the reduction of the max imum tar iff rate from 150 per cent to 60 per cent. As a result, the unweighted average tariff was reduced to 35 per cent f rom 39 per cent at the end of 1979. The Philippines substantially reduced ta r i f fs on more than 500 items in January 1981, as the first step of a comprehensive program to reform the tariff structure. Uruguay continued its tariff reform program by lowering for the second year sur- charges, ta r i f fs, and other import levies at the end of 1980 by 16 per cent of the difference between the sum of the various existing levies and the target duty rate of 35 per cent. Ta r i f fs covering a wide range of items were also reduced, temporarily sus- pended, or removed in Algeria, Argentina, Egypt, Singapore, and Venezuela. Indonesia also lowered or withdrew duties and sales taxes on a wide range of imports while introducing duties on a few of them. Maldives lowered duties on most imports but discontinued duty exemption for private imports. Other countries which selectively reduced tar iffs included Korea and Pakistan. 15 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS A number of countries increased the rates of customs duties and other import taxes. Among industrial countries, Iceland introduced protective duties on recently liberalized imports of biscuits, sugar confectionary, and chocolates. New Zealand raised duties on a variety of beers, spirits, and coir mats and matting. The United States increased duties on imports of certain cookware and preserved mushrooms under GATT Article XIX. Among developing countries, Ghana, Kenya, Mexico, and Senegal raised customs duties on a wide range of goods, while Cyprus introduced duties on many lux- ury imports. Selective tariff increases were under- taken in Fiji, Korea, Kuwait, Malta, Nepal, Oman, Paraguay, Seychelles, Sri Lanka, and Western Samoa. Antidumping and countervailing duties were im- posed on a variety of products by several countries, including one developing country. Argentina imposed a countervailing duty on photocopying paper and an antidumping du ty on textiles, both from Brazil. Australia imposed antidumping duties on several import categories, including high-speed twist drills from Czechoslovakia and carton boards from Austria, Finland, the Federal Republic of Germany, the Netherlands, and Spain. Canada and the EC also imposed antidumping duties on a num- ber of commodities. In the United States, antidump- ing duties were assessed on four categories of imports, and countervailing duties were imposed in several cases, the most important being industrial fasteners and iron metal castings from India and pig iron from Brazil. c. Advance Import Deposits In contrast to 1979, when there was an increase in the reliance on advance import deposit require- ments, cases of elimination and liberalization were more numerous than those of introduction and in- tensification of new deposit schemes in the period under review. Advance import deposit requirements were abol- ished in Bolivia, Iceland, Israel, and Nigeria. Ecua- dor exempted a number of imports from its deposit requirement and permitted, for certain import cate- gories, the fulfillment of up to 25 per cent of the deposit requirement in the form of mortgage or government bonds. Greece abolished in April 1980 the additional advance import deposit requirement of 75 per cent introduced in late 1979 and lowered at the start of 1981 by 25 per cent the schedule of rates on the remaining two advance deposits, the prepayment and the security deposit schemes. Korea, which requires advance deposits only on 16 private imports financed on a deferred payments basis, lowered the rate on such imports of copper from 20 per cent to 10 per cent. Morocco exempted imports of capital goods from its advance import deposit requirement. In the first half of 1980 Paki- stan exempted various products from the minimum margin requirements on the opening of import letters of credit and transferred other products to lower rates. In July 1980 a new comprehensive list of margin requirements was issued which reduced the maximum margin from 100 per cent to 35 per cent. Turkey lowered the rates of its advance import deposit scheme from a range of 25-40 per cent to a range of 10-30 per cent, but subjected previously exempt public sector imports to the 10 per cent rate. Deposit requirements were introduced by Costa Rica and Guatemala. As part of a set of emergency measures introduced in September 1980, Costa Rica began requiring a prior deposit to be held for six months, ranging from 10-50 per cent of import value, upon registration of the import orders with the Central Bank; excluded from this requirement were certain imports which also were exempted from the simultaneously imposed temporary surcharges. In April 1980 Guatemala introduced a 25 per cent guarantee deposit to be made at the time of request- ing foreign exchange for the prepayment of most imports. Existing import deposit requirements were tightened by the Dominican Republic and El Salvador. d. Other Measures Affecting Import Payments Official regulations governing the terms of import payments were relaxed in several countries. Chile allowed import payments to exceed values originally registered with the Central Bank by up to US$10,000 without further approval. It also extended from 120 days to 150 days the maximum delay within which exchange cover must be secured for import pay- ments not on a deferred basis. Ghana permitted suppliers' credit financing for specified import cate- gories. Korea extended the settlement period for imports with deferred payment fur ther from 120 days to 180 days, while also expanding the coverage in value terms of goods eligible for deferred pay- ment; it also permitted oil importers and refineries to receive short-term foreign currency loans for crude oil imports payable within 180 days and eliminated the limitation on import credits for major raw materials. The Philippines permitted authorized banks to sell foreign exchange for certain restricted categories of imports without prior approval from January 1981. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAIN DEVELOPMENTS IN RESTRICTIVE PRACTICES Import payments regulations were tightened in the Dominican Republic, where imports of machin- ery, equipment, and spare parts were added to the list of imports which did not receive foreign exchange cover through the Central Bank. Also, commercial bank liabilities resulting from unprepaid letters of credit which were opened on or after September 1, 1980 were subjected to a 100 per cent reserve requirement. Brazil prescribed external financing satisfying specified minimum maturities for imports of capital goods, spare parts, and raw materials and consumer durables, subject to certain specified exemptions. Guatemala required the registration of all imports except those from countries adhering to the General Treaty of Central American Economic Integration. Similarly, Rwanda required the sub- mission of a copy of the bill of lading before autho- rizing payments for imports. Western Samoa required prior approval for public sector requests for foreign exchange in excess of WS$5,000 and all letters of credit in excess of WS$ 10,000; in July 1980 it also prohibited imports of motor vehicles for the remainder of 1980 except those approved by the Monetary Board or where financing was effected through remittance of overseas funds. Zambia pro- hibited authorized dealers from providing foreign exchange for goods whose value did not exceed K 50 and for which no import license was produced. e. State Trading The reliance on state trading increased to a mod- erate extent during the review period. There were selective relaxations in Pakistan and Sri Lanka, where the importation of certain nonferrous metals and mercury (Pakistan) and of rice, wheat, and wheat flour (Sri Lanka) were opened to the private sector. On the other hand, Iran announced in March 1980 that all foreign trade would be conducted by government agencies; although individual importers could initiate the importation of goods, the actual importation must be carried out through govern- ment-operated import agencies. Iraq centralized the import of many products under the government importing agency. Ivory Coast required that the importation of chemical fertilizers be conducted by a public enterprise specializing in agricultural exten- sion services. Malta expanded the system operated by the Government of buying essential commodities in bulk to about 40 items. In early 1981 Seychelles extended the monopoly rights of the Seychelles National Commodity Company from all exports to imports of a variety of essential food items. 2. Exports and Export Proceeds As in previous years, many countries resorted to a variety of fiscal, credit, and exchange rate guarantee measures to stimulate exports. Such measures were generally tailored to the needs of particular export sectors. In contrast, the use of quantitative restric- tions on specific products was usually motivated by domestic supply considerations, including the con- cern about price increases. In certain sectors, how- ever, exporting countries exercised restraint in accordance with agreements reached with importing countries. More comprehensive trade sanctions were taken by some countries as a result of political con- siderations. Reflecting the difficult external pay- ments situation of non-oil developing countries, significantly more countries than in recent years tightened their surrender requirements on export proceeds. New fiscal measures to promote exports were taken predominantly by developing countries. Dur- ing 1980 Argentina extended its rebate scheme to a wide range of agricultural and manufac tured exports but decided in December to phase out all export rebates by January 1, 1986. Brazil reinstated in April 1981 tax credits for selected manufactured exports v/hich had been suspended in connection with the December 1979 exchange reform. Kenya dou- bled the rate of compensation paid on eligible exports to 20 per cent of f.o.b. value and extended the coverage of the scheme to all but certain specified exports. To rationalize its export incentive schemes, New Zealand introduced three new schemes, viz., the Export Performance Taxation Incentive, the Export Program Grants Scheme, and the Export Market Development Taxation Incentive. Paki- stan extended the coverage of its rebate scheme to three types of manufactured exports. The Philip- pines extended the privileges enjoyed by export- oriented firms to enterprises located in export- processing zones. Senegal began to subsidize nontraditional exports at a rate of 10 per cent of f.o.b. value. Af ter granting tax credit certificates to the exports of various additional products, Uru- guay in August established a program calling for the gradual reduction of tax credit certificate rates to a un i fo rm rate of 5 per cent of the f.o.b. export value between January 1, 1982 and January 1, 1985. Countries that took steps to curtail or eliminate their reliance on fiscal export incentives included India, Peru, and Zimbabwe. A review by the OECD of its guidelines for offi- cially supported export credits in May 1980 led to a modest upward adjustment in minimum interest rates, which are maintained uniformly by all OECD member countries, irrespective of the currency in 17 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS which the export credit is denominated. With effect from July 1, 1980, the minimum rates were increased by 3A percentage point for officially supported export credits to the "intermediate" and "relatively rich" countries and by V* percentage point for the "rela- tively poor" countries. Negotiations to review the minimum interest rates in December 1980 and May 1981 remained inconclusive. A full review of the 1978 guidelines is to be completed by October 1981. Several countries provided or improved preferen- tial financing facilities for exporters. Argentina granted eligibility for prefinancing of promoted exports to a number of meat products and by-prod- ucts. In 1981 Canada introduced a program which will provide a combination of commercial and con- cessional export credits as a means of reducing the effective interest rate on export financing. As a part of a relaxation of its exchange controls, France pro- vided more liberal authorization for export-related financial credits denominated in francs. Korea extended the scope for the use of funds received under swaps to include export financing. Pakistan applied simplified procedures for exporters seeking credit under the Export Finance Scheme. Peru created a special fund in the Central Reserve Bank to finance up to 70 per cent of capital goods exports and related services. Viet Nam established a foreign exchange fund to provide credits to domestic pro- ducers to finance imports of inputs for exports in excess of Plan targets or outside the Plan'. On the other hand, Greece reduced the subsidy on interest rates for exports to EC countries, and in Switzer- land the National Bank and the commercial banks agreed not to renew their 1975 agreement under which the banks were prepared to discount at prefer- ential rates export bills of exchange with maturities of up to six months. A number of countries, most of them developed, amended their system of guarantees and insurance on export credits as well as guarantees against exchange rate risks. Chile extended the repayment period for export credits and the time allowed for shipping merchandise under export credit arrange- ments. In the United Kingdom the Export Credit Guarantee Department (ECGD) announced that it would no longer insist on exporters financing large, specifically guaranteed overseas contracts in foreign currencies under its fixed-rate export finance scheme. On the other hand, the ECGD withdrew the refi- nance facility provided for certain fixed interest rate sterling export credits. In addition, the Credit and Guarantee Insurance Company (CGIC) announced in September a new scheme enabling customers to claim compensation from the CGIC in the event of a 18 breach of contract by the exporter. In South Africa, the Credit Guarantee Insurance Corporation set a limit of 25 per cent of the previous year's sales on credit insurance for exports to Zimbabwe. Switzer- land extended until November 1981 the facility of currency options under which exporters of goods and services can cover their exchange risks with the National Bank for up to two years forward. Countries imposing or intensifying quantitative restrictions on exports by far outnumbered those which relaxed or eliminated such restrictions. Clearance, declaration, or licensing requirements were lifted on a selective basis in Canada, the Philip- pines, Venezuela, and Western Samoa, while a few quantitative controls were lifted in the United Kingdom. On the restrictive side, the most significant measures were the coordinated embargoes by several predominantly developed countries against Iran and the U.S.S.R. Major industrial countries banned the export of goods and services to Iran, except food and medicines. Restrictions against Iran began to be lifted in late 1980 and early 1981. In January 1980 the United States suspended the shipment of certain agricultural products, notably corn and wheat, to the U.S.S.R. Export licenses for corn and wheat were granted, however, up to the extent necessary to per- mit shipments under the 1975 agreement between both countries.18 The U.S. measure received sup- port from other major corn and wheat producers such as Australia, Canada, and the EC. The United States also suspended all outstanding licenses for exports of high-technology products to the U.S.S.R. Controls on specified exports in the form of bans, quotas, licensing, and certain other requirements were also introduced or intensified in Guatemala, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan, Peru, Thailand, Turkey, the United Kingdom, and Yugoslavia. Domestic supply or government revenue con- siderations accounted for most of the many changes in export taxation. Numerous, on balance liberaliz- ing, changes took place in Brazil's complex export taxation system during 1980. Export taxes were abolished successively for soybeans, sisal, and cocoa. New lists or modifications to previous lists of prod- ucts subject to export taxes were issued on five occasions during the year; most of these modifica- tions resulted in a reduction of the rate of taxation. The contribution quota for the export of quartz chips was abolished in October 1980. Exports of orange juice were made subject to a temporary contribution quota that applied during the second half of 1980 18 The restrictions on grain exports to the U.S.S.R. were lifted on April 24, 1981. ©International Monetary Fund.
