Colombia reduced the tax on the proceeds from coffee exports and removed such exports from the list of commodi- ties subject to a forced discount upon early surrender of exchange certificates issued against export pro- ceeds. Export duties, taxes, or other levies on spe- cific commodities were also reduced in Nepal, the Philippines, Sudan, and Thailand and abolished in Argentina, the People's Republic of China, Mexico, Nepal, and the Philippines. Countries introducing new or raising existing export levies on specified products included Argentina, Canada, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Sudan. Mauritius introduced a sur- charge on existing export duties. In most instances, measures relaxing surrender requirements lengthened the period for which foreign exchange could be retained, or introduced or increased retention quotas for exporters. As part of a package of measures relaxing exchange controls, France in June 1980 authorized exporters to retain foreign exchange received in payment until covering contracts actually matured (as against a limit of eight days previously) and extended to all exporters the privilege of making deposits to foreign bank accounts up to certain monthly limits. The maximum period for the surrender of export proceeds was also extended in Korea and Portugal. Maldives rescinded a 50 per cent surrender requirement for certain exports introduced in 1979. Pakistan waived the declaration requirement for exchange surrender pur- poses in the case of goods manufac tured in export processing zones. Turkey extended the retention quota scheme to exporters of certain agricultural products and to the exchange earnings of Turkish contractors. Zaire, which temporarily tightened the surrender regulations for its major mining company, permitted producer-exporters to retain a specified fraction of their export proceeds subject to certain conditions. A special differentiated retention scheme for the coffee sector was introduced later in 1980. Several changes in Peru's surrender requirements of export proceeds, including the introduction of non- negotiable interest-bearing exchange certificates with a maturity of 90 days up to specified percentages of most traditional exports, were introduced for do- mestic liquidity control reasons. Surrender require- ments were tightened in a number of countries, often in response to acute balance of payments pressures. Brazil set an outside limit of 10 days af ter shipment for the surrender of export proceeds. With the exemption of certain public sector authorities and entities, Egypt lowered the retention quotas and surrender periods for the private and public sector, respectively. El Salvador centralized the collection of exchange proceeds from its major exports in the Central Reserve Bank. Similarly, Guatemala made the approval of export licenses conditional upon agreement by the exporters to surrender their export proceeds to the Bank of Guatemala within a set time limit. Honduras required all exporters benefit- ing from domestic credit or guarantee endorsements from domestic banks to surrender their export pro- ceeds. Israel instructed all exporters to repatriate their export proceeds without delay. In the final quarter of 1980 Italy temporarily reduced the maxi- mum period for the retention of export proceeds f rom 15 days to 10 days. Ivory Coast reduced the repatriation period for export transactions and required that such repatriation be made to Ivory Coast. Zimbabwe subjected exports to 50 countries to payment in designated currencies and required either advance payment or the prior establishment of an irrevocable letter of credit. 3. Current Invisibles During the period under review Fund members appear, on balance, to have liberalized their regula- tions on current invisibles. Although there were some substantial increases in nominal exchange allocations for specified payments for invisibles, the increases were offset in varying degrees by concur- rent price increases. Moreover, several countries tightened restrictions in response to severe balance of payments pressures. Most of the measures taken, whether to ease or tighten restrictions, were, as in recent years, in the area of exchange allocations or allowances for tourism and other travel abroad. To a lesser extent, steps were also taken regarding remittances of incomes and profits, as well as the import and export of notes and coins. Among developed countries, Iceland, Italy, and Norway substantially increased their basic exchange allocations for travel, the latter country by 100 per cent. Sweden doubled the allocation for longer journeys. Italy also raised the allowances for busi- ness travel, medical treatment, and education, while maintaining a restriction on foreign exchange made available for foreign tourism. In developing coun- tries, the limits on basic travel allowances were more than doubled in Chile and the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya and removed altogether in Mauritania. In Greece, the travel allowance was raised for travel to EC countries only. Peru doubled its indicative ceiling for foreign travel. South Africa also increased its travel allowance substantially, and Zambia raised its basic allocation by two thirds, with a lower limit applying to surface travel in continental Africa. 19 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS Business travel allowances were liberalized in a number of developing countries by raising the daily allocations (Mauritius, Peru, and Zambia), the indi- cative overall ceiling (Peru), or the maximum length of stay (Zambia). In Pakistan, the blanket permis- sion for business travel was liberalized by doubling the validity period of such permission to one year and by permitting simultaneous travel by two representa- tives of the same firm urider specified conditions. Increases of business travel allocations in the Philip- pines were granted to exporters, depending on country of destination and size of firm. With respect to exchange for other types of foreign travel, Pakistan simplified the procedures for pil- grimage travel to Saudi Arabia and raised the allow- ances for living and other expenses for students abroad. Peru doubled the indicative exchange alloca- tion for student travel and for the personnel on Peru- vian international carriers; in addition, the limit on sales of foreign exchange to departing nonresidents was raised from US$50 to US$500. Finally, South Africa raised the maintenance and study allowances. Access to foreign exchange for travel purposes was restricted in a number of developing countries, in nearly all cases as a result of exchange shortages. Besides outright reductions in amounts, travel taxes and deposit requirements were used along with administrative restrictions. Barbados cut the allow- ance for business travel inside the Caribbean Com- mon Market (CARICOM) area by one third. Rein- forcing restrictive action taken in 1979, El Salvador severely tightened restrictions on the sale of foreign exchange for foreign tourism, education, and family assistance. In Ghana, the tax rates on travel tickets and travel exchange were raised to a un iform rate of 75 per cent and exchange allocations for medical and educational expenses also became subject to the tax. Guatemala, which previously had no restrictions on payments for invisibles, introduced a refundable 10 per cent deposit requirement on exchange pur- chases for nonbusiness travel outside Central America in excess of US$1,500 a person. Also, limits were introduced for that type of travel and certain other current invisibles with waiver provisions for bona fide cases. As in 1979, Iran again reduced its basic travel allocation. In February 1981 Madagascar reduced by one third the annual limits on the basic travel allocation and the business travel allocation. Finally, in Sierra Leone nonresidents were no longer allowed to purchase airline tickets with local cur- rency. In addition to the above-mentioned measures, Colombia doubled its travel tax and expressed the tax liability in U.S. dollars instead of pesos previously. 20 A few countries eased their regulations on remit- tances of various categories of income. Upon its accession to the EC at the start of 1981, Greece abolished all restrictions on the transfer of dividends, interest, and profits to the EC countries. Mauritania removed limitations on salary transfers, while Para- guay softened the application of its 30 per cent remittance tax in the case of foreign loans contracted by domestic banks. From March 1980, the tax was payable only on the spread in the case of flexible interest loans or on the first 6l/2 per cent of interest in the case of fixed-rate loans. Portugal ceased to apply phasing requirements for the remittance of d iv idends and profits exceeding US$250,000. Zim- babwe, which also restricted the remittance of dividends in certain cases (see be low), permitted shareholders to remit freely dividends for financial years ending on or af ter March 31, 1981, provided t h at these dividends do not exceed 50 per cent of the af ter- tax profit of the company concerned. Pro- vision was also made for the gradual release of blocked dividends, interest, and other incomes which had accrued to residents of Canada, the United Kingdom, and the United States ( the designated coun t r ies) during the years 1965-73, and for the remittance of 50 per cent of the profits earned by branches of companies other than insurance com- panies in the designated countries during this period. Furthermore, Zimbabwe permitted the transfer of interest accrued on blocked funds from July 1, 1980 to companies in designated countries. Remittances abroad were restricted in Thailand, which reinstated a 10 per cent withholding tax on interest paymen ts abroad for obligations of less than one year's ma tur i ty, and in Western Samoa, which applied a 15 per cent withholding tax on the remit- tance of interest. Zaire limited the transfer of expatriate salaries in 1980 to the level authorized for 1979. In Zambia, the transfer abroad of leave pay for foreign nationals was limited to one third of the total of such pay, and this amount plus the full amount of any gratuity became subject to the overall limit of K 8,000 on departure. In Zimbabwe, certain shareholders who had hitherto enjoyed the free trans- fer of their dividends were permitted to remit divi- dends declared, for financial years ended af ter June 30, 1980, only where the total dividend so declared by a company does not exceed 50 per cent of its af ter- tax profit. Among other measures affecting payments for current invisible transactions, Austria doubled the limit on outward invisible payments not subject to licensing, and Chile raised the exchange allocation ©International Monetary Fund. The Philippines made nontrade foreign exchange earners eligible for registration with the Central Bank as "export oriented," thus granting them access to cer- tain incentives. South Africa substantially raised the annual limit on gifts abroad. In January 1981 the United States eliminated with one exception the restrictions on payments and transfers for current international transactions with Iran that had been introduced for security reasons in 1979 and 1980. Several countries changed the limits for the hold- ing, import, and export of foreign and domestic means of payment. Fiji raised the limits on domestic and foreign currency notes that travelers are per- mitted to take abroad, while Norway more than doubled the amount in Norwegian banknotes that each person leaving Norway may carry. In contrast, El Salvador required customs declaration of local currency brought in and out of the country, and Honduras restricted the amount of foreign currency notes and coins purchased by persons traveling abroad to US$100 a person a year. In Israel, the amount of foreign currency residents are authorized to hold in cash form was reduced from US$3,000 to US$500; the balance from the US$3,000 previously allowed must be held in travelers checks or bank checks. Bank transfers of non-Israeli currency by residents within the country were made illegal. 4. Payments Arrears In October 1980 the Executive Board of the Fund undertook a comprehensive review of the Fund's experience with, and its policies and procedures on, external payments arrears. The review took place against the background of a substantial increase, since the preceding review in October 1970, in the number of countries incurring payments arrears and in the total amount of arrears outstanding. The Fund's concern with arrears stems not only from the harmful effects on creditor countries and their, deleterious consequences for the credit standing of the members incurring them but also from their injurious effects on the smooth func t ion ing of the international trade and payments system. In con- cluding the review, the Executive Board broadly endorsed the procedures and policy guidelines which had been followed during the preceding decade, while specifying that some minor modifications were necessary in light of the Fund's experience with arrears in the intervening period. Payments arrears are exchange restrictions which arise from governmentally imposed delays, beyond those required by normal adm in is t ra t ive procedures, in the provision of foreign exchange for the mak ing of paymen ts and transfers recognized as legitimate under a country's exchange control system. The Fund's approval jurisdiction on exchange restrictions under Article VIII, Section 2 becomes involved whenever such governmental action causes an undue delay in the mak ing of paymen ts and t rans fe rs for cu r rent in te rna t ional transactions. What constitutes an undue delay needs to be examined in a flexible and pragmatic manner on a case-by-case basis, hav ing regard to the administrative procedures and other circumstances of the member concerned. Because of the damaging effects of arrears on the in terna t ional t rade and payments system, the Fund does not grant approval to payments arrears which are exchange restrictions w i th in the mean ing of Article VIII, Section 2, except where the member has presented a program for the reduction and/or the eventual elimination of such arrears. When pay- ments arrears are incurred by a government or by a government entity, the financial operations of which clearly form part of the budge tary process, and in those cases in wh ich arrears arise because a coun t ry belonging to a common central bank is unable to obtain domestic currency in order to pur- chase required foreign exchange, the arrears are treated as defaults and not as exchange restrictions within the meaning of Article VIII. In the settlement of payments arrears, member countries are expected to observe the principle of nondiscrimination as regards creditor countries. The Fund is also concerned w i th the trea tment of payments arrears in the context of stabilization pro- grams supported by use of the Fund's resources. In these programs, member countries are expected to take steps to reduce and eventually eliminate pay- ments arrears (including those arising from govern- mental d e f au l t) relating to capital transactions, as well as to paymen ts and transfers for current inter- national transactions. However, in view of the recent experience in some member countries, the Fund recognizes that when payments arrears are large in relation to a member's available foreign exchange resources, it may not be possible to aim at the e l im ina t ion of the arrears within the program period. The renegotiation of outstanding debt obligations (including arrears) may become necessary when debt problems are particularly severe. Depending on the member's circumstances and the length of the program, it may, in the early stages of a program, only be possible to reach understandings as to the avoidance of any fu r ther increase in arrears. In 21 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANG EM EN TS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS general, Fund financial assistance to members with payments arrears will continue to be granted, as before, on the basis of performance criteria or poli- cies with respect to arrears in recognition of their status as payments restrictions. All of the countries which had payments arrears (including those arising from governmental defaults) in 1979 continued to do so during 1980. At the end of 1980, external payments arrears were known to exist in 26 countries,19 compared with 13 countries at the end of 1975. Their totfil was estimated to amount to about SDR 5.3 billion, or only slightly less than the total estimated for the end of 1979, compared with SDR 0.7 billion at the end of 1975. Without the substantial amount of debt service arrears rescheduled during 1980, notably by the creditors of Nicaragua, Turkey, and Zaire, the end-1980 total would have been considerably higher. While the arrears total of the 26 countries repre- sented some 42 per cent of their aggregate 1980 exports (as compared to just under 10 per cent of the 1975 exports of countries then incurring a r rea r s ), the problem of the backlog in payments was much more severe in a few individual cases, reaching as high as 230 per cent of 1980 exports in one case. Of the 26 countries with arrears, 20 had comprehensive adjustment programs in effect dur ing 1980 or early 1981 which envisaged the orderly reduction or elimination of the arrears and which provided the countries access to the Fund's resources, in all but one case in the higher credit tranches. The arrears recorded at the end of 1980 involved payments and transfers for current international transactions on account of commercial imports, as well as official and private debt service. In some of the countries, arrears also represented delays in the provision of foreign exchange for other current invisibles, such as the remittance of profits and dividends on foreign investment and of earnings by international airline companies. In some of these instances, however, it is difficult to determine whether such delays in fact constitute genuine cases of payments arrears, because the time period con- sidered necessary by the authorities to process appli- 19 Bolivia*, Central African Republic*, Chad, People's Republic of the Congo*, Costa Rica*, Dominican Republic, The Gambia, Ghana*, Grenada*, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Guyana*, Jamaica*, Madagascar*, Mauritania*, Nicaragua, Senegal*, Sierra Leone*, Somalia*, Sudan*, Tanzania*, Togo*, Turkey*, Uganda*, Zaire*, and Zambia*. Available data indicate that there was an increase in outstanding arrears between the end of 1979 and the end of 1980 in Bolivia, Central African Republic, Dominican Republic, Guyana, Jamaica, Madagascar, Sierra Leone, Sudan, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia. In Costa Rica, The Gambia, and Senegal arrears began to accrue in the course of 1980. During 1980 reduc- tions in arrears were recorded in 5 countries, 4 of which had entered into programs supported by the use of Fund resources. Ranked in ascending order of the amount of reduction, those countries were Togo, Ghana, Nicaragua, Turkey, and Zaire. In addition to the reduction of arrears through cash payment, the latter 3 countries benefited from debt renegotiation agreements with major creditors or creditor groups that included the refinancing or rescheduling of arrears on debt service payments. Among the 26 member countries with arrears at the end of 1980, there were 6 which share common currency arrangements as members of the Bank of Central Afr ican States (BEAC ), the Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO), or the East Carib- bean Currency Au thor i ty (ECCA) .20 In those coun- tries arrears represent overdue obligations to both external and internal creditors. Arrears emerge in those countries because the authorities do not have adequate recourse to domestic currency to purchase foreign exchange from the joint central bank as a result of statutory limits on lending by the joint central bank to the participating governments. As the emergence of this type of governmental default partly reflects a deterioration in the respective gov- ernment's financial operations, 5 of the 6 members experiencing this problem have entered into stabiliza- tion programs supported by financial assistance from the Fund which, inter alia, include policies aimed at strengthening the government's budgetary position. 5. Multiple Currency Practices With the entry into force of the Second Amend- ment to the Articles of Agreement on April 1, 1978, Fund member countries were given the right to adopt exchange arrangements of their choice. The freedom to select exchange arrangements, which is stipulated in Article IV, Section 2 ( 6 ), is subject to the special obligations regarding exchange arrangements (in the 20 They were the Central Afr ican Republic, Chad, and the People's Republic of the Congo f rom the BEAC, Senegal and Togo from the BCEAO, and Grenada from the ECCA. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAIN DEVELOPMENTS IN RESTRICTIVE PRACTICES present context especially that of maintenance of orderly exchange arrangements according to Arti- cle IV, Section 1) and to the general obligations of members according to Article VIII which proscribe, inter alia, the use of multiple currency practices and discriminatory currency arrangements. In the absence of any definition provided by the Articles of Agreement, the Fund has authority to give content to the concept of multiple currency practices. Follow- ing the Second Amendment, the Fund, in implement- ing its policy with regard to multiple currency practices, continued to apply the approaches and criteria it had been following in accordance with the revised decision on central rates and wider margins.21 In accordance with a review in October 1979 of the legal and operational aspects of multiple currency practices, the Executive Board clarified that, under the Second Amendment, only multiple currency practices resulting from official action come under the Fund's jurisdiction under Article VIII, Section 3.22 In March 1981 the Executive Board again reviewed the Fund's policy with respect to multiple currency practices and adopted guidelines defining multiple currency practices and broken cross rates and out- lining the Fund's fu tu re policy in the exercise of its approval jurisdiction over such practices.23 According to the new criteria, a multiple currency practice arises from action by a member or its fiscal agencies that either (1) of itself gives rise to a spread of more than 2 per cent between buying and selling rates for spot exchange transactions between the member's currency and any other member's cur- rency or (2) results in midpoint spot exchange rates of other members' currencies against its own cur- rency in a relationship which differs by more than 1 per cent from the midpoint spot exchange rates for these currencies in their principal markets. The new 21 That decision, No. 4083-(73/104), adopted on Novem- ber 7, 1973, stated in paragraph 5 that . .. no member shall permit, except as approved or authorized under Article VIII, Section 3 or Article XIV, Section 2: a difference in excess of 2 per cent between any two buying or any two selling rates for spot exchange transactions between its currency and the currencies of other members; or a spread in excess of 2 per cent between a buying and a selling rate for spot exchange transactions between its currency and the currency of another member. 22 The outcome of the 1979 review was summarized in the Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions, 1980, page 17. 23 The full text of the conclusions, which were adopted by the Executive Board on March 20, 1981 as Decision No. 6790-(81/43), is reproduced in the Annex, page 36. criteria are intended to give consideration to the particular circumstances of members. Exchange spreads resulting from commercial costs and exchange risk as such are, therefore, no longer considered in ascertaining the existence of a multiple currency practice. Similarly, such costs and even official actions are not taken into account by basing the cal- culation of broken cross rates on midpoint exchange rates. Moreover, broken cross rates of more than 1 per cent become subject to the Fund's approval jurisdiction under Article VIII, Section 3, only if they exist for more than one week. This gives recognition to the increased likelihood of breaks for countries pegging to one individual currency, or to one or more currencies, or to a composite of cur- rencies as a result of the greater volatility of exchange rates under the exchange arrangements permitted under the Second Amendment. As in the past, countries are required to seek prior approval for the introduction of multiple currency practices. Except for multiple currency practices arising from broken cross rates, which are inherently discriminatory, such approval will be granted for no more than approximately one year, if the multiple currency practice is introduced or maintained for balance of payments reasons, and the Fund is satis- fied with the member's representation that the measure is necessary, that it does not provide the member an unfa ir competitive advantage, and that it is applied on a temporary and nondiscriminatory basis while the member is taking steps to solve its balance of payments problem. The Fund is also prepared to grant temporary approval to multiple currency practices introduced or maintained prin- cipally for nonbalance of payments reasons, pro- vided that such practices do not materially impede the member's balance of payments adjustment, do not harm the interests of other members, and do not discriminate among members. Classified into broad categories, multiple currency practices encompass separate exchange rates, either through the mechanism of a dual or multiple exchange market or the establishment of separate official exchange rates for specified transactions, broken cross rates, or other discriminatory currency arrangements and, in a large number of cases, a variety of exchange measures creating excessive exchange rate spreads. In any given year during the period 1970-80, between 25 per cent and 48 per cent of members were engaging in multiple currency practices in accordance with the Fund's interpreta- tion of the term. In absolute terms, their incidence rose moderately until 1978 from a low recorded in 1974 but declined again during 1979 and 1980. In 23 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS the course of 1980, 43 members had at least one multiple currency practice (compared with 48 during 1979), and there was substantial progress in reduc- ing members' reliance on multiple currency practices. Seven members abolished their remaining multiple currency practices,24 while only 3 members were added to the list of countries engaging in multiple currency practices.25 In addition to those 3 countries, there were only 2 countries which introduced a new multiple currency practice. Among countries with multiple exchange market arrangements, Nepal reduced to one half the rate differential for the U.S. dollar by appreciating the more depreciated second ra te from NRs 16 to NRs 14 per US$1, while maintaining the basic rate at NRs 12 per US$1. The rate applying to trans- actions with India remained unchanged at NRs 145 per Rs 100. In the course of 1980 Nicaragua expanded the scope of the market in which permitted exchange transactions take place at freely determined rates. As during 1971-74, Costa Rica split the exchange market in September 1980 by permitting exporters to sell 50 per cent of their exchange proceeds in the parallel market and by restricting access to the official market to specified types of transactions, notably to those by the public sector and to 50 per cent of most private sector imports. In December Costa Rica reunified the exchange market at a rate which was largely determined on the basis of demand and supply conditions. For the time being, some multiple currency practices continue to result, however, from the temporary provision until the end of 1981 of exchange to the Central Govern- ment at the former official exchange rate and from the provision of exchange at that same rate for certain medical.and educational payments abroad approved prior to September 1980. Exchange continued to be provided for the afore-mentioned transactions at the rate of <£ 8.60 per US$1 af ter the renewed separation of the exchange markets in March 1981 and their subsequent reunification in April 1981. A large number of countries reduced their reliance on multiple currency practices by a variety of meas- ures, including the abolition of special rates, the reduction in the dispersion of rates, or the narrow- ing of the scope of transactions covered by special rates. As mentioned in the section on exports, Brazil modified on various occasions during the 24 Maldives, Mauritania, Morocco, Pakistan, Somalia, Uruguay, and Zaire. 25 Barbados, People's Republic of China, and Costa Rica. 24 review period its taxes and contribution quotas on exports. Export taxes on cocoa, soybeans, and sisal were eliminated between April and September, and the contribution quota on quartz chips was abolished in October. The rate of taxation for other products was also reduced in connection with the issuance of new and modified lists of products subject to export taxes. Colombia also took several steps to reduce the scope of its multiple currency practices. From the beginning of 1980, exports under official export- import regimes became eligible for exchange-related benefits in the form of freely negotiable tax credit certificates at a rate of 0.1 per cent of surrendered export earnings; previously, rates of up to 12 per cent were applied to the added value of certain exports, depending on the commodity. Also in January 1980, the coverage of the special tax on outward remittances was reduced by excluding rental payments for television movies. In October coffee exports were exempted from the forced dis- count of 5 per cent on the early encashment of exchange certificates, and in December the coffee export tax was reduced from 16 per cent to 13 per cent of export proceeds. In accordance with its obligations under the Accession Treaty with the EC to eliminate its advance import deposit requirements over a four-year period, Greece abolished one deposit requirement and lowered the rates on the remaining two. Maldives repealed in April 1980 a 50 per cent surrender requirement at a substantially appreciated rate for certain fish exports. In March 1980 Mauritania abolished the fixed exchange rates for transactions in banknotes for specified currencies, thereby permitting such transactions to be effected on the basis of the official exchange rate. With effect from January 1, 1981 Morocco terminated the 5 per cent bonus on the inward remittances through the banking and postal systems by Moroccans work- ing abroad. By substantially reducing the minimum margin requirements on import letters of credit from a max imum of 100 per cent to a maximum of 35 per cent in July 1980, Pakistan eliminated a multiple currency practice which had existed for about one year. Somalia removed the prescribed commission on foreign exchange transactions in January 1980. In September 1980 Sudan shifted the proceeds from all exports other than cotton and the payments for all imports other than specified essential items from the official market to the more depreciated parallel mar- ket. Turkey abolished its special exchange rates for workers' remittances and for the sale of exchange for tourism abroad in connection with the January 1980 devaluation of the lira to LT 70 = US$1. After the ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAIN DEVELOPMENTS IN RESTRICTIVE PRACTICES devaluation, new multiple currency practices arose (1) for imports of fertilizers and insecticides, as well as of the inputs for their domestic production, for which exchange was sold at a preferential rate of LT 55 = US$1; (2) for expenses of students, on a temporary basis, who had commenced their study abroad prior to certain dates (minimum rate of LT 26.50 = US$1 ); (3) for exports of goods and services effected prior to the devaluation, the unre- patriated part of which would be eligible for the predevaluation exchange rate plus a premium of LT 5 per US$1 if the exchange earnings were remitted to Turkey at least one month in advance of due date (LT 47.10 = US$1 or LT 52.10 = US$1); and (4) for foreign exporters with nonguaranteed overdue claims who chose the Turkish lira option for settlement (LT 47.10 = US$1). In June 1980 exporters of fresh vegetables, fru i ts, and fish became eligible to retain 10 per cent of their proceeds. As there is an active exchange market in such exchange balances, a multiple currency practice can arise from this arrangement, depending on the size of the premium. The retention scheme was also extended at the rate of 10 per cent to foreign exchange earn- ings of Turkish contractors. Uruguay abolished its last multiple currency practice in April 1980 by replacing the exchange tax on proceeds from exports of animal hides by an equivalent export tax. In accordance with an undertaking under its stabiliza- tion program with the Fund, Zaire abolished in February 1980 the preferential exchange rate for diamonds purchased from small-scale producers. Actions creating new or intensifying existing mul- tiple currency practices were reported in only six countries. In May 1980 Barbados introduced fees, ranging as high as 4 per cent of the value of the transaction, on purchases of foreign exchange for private sector remittances abroad with the exception of import payments, travel and education allowances, and nontrade payments of over BDS$500. In April 1980 Brazil extended the tax on financial operations, which had long been levied on domestic financial operations, to cover exchange purchases for imports and specified services. At the end of 1980 the tax rate on exchange purchases for certain imports was raised f rom 15 per cent to 25 per cent, and in March 1981 a special rate of 20 per cent was created for imports from countries which are members of the Latin American Integration Association (LAIA). Brazil also introduced a temporary contribution quota on the export of orange juice during the second half of 1980; this measure lapsed on December 31, 1980. In September 1980 the People's Republic of China imposed a 10 per cent tax on profit remit- tances by joint ventures, and at the start of 1981 an internal settlement rate of Y 2.8 per US$1 was introduced for the settlement of trade and trade- related transactions between trading organizations and the Bank of China. On an experimental basis, trading organizations could retain a portion of their proceeds and sell it at the new internal settlement rate to other enterprises having a quota to use foreign exchange. In late 1980 the Dominican Republic exempted more than 40 export products, par t ly or fully, from the surrender requirement, thus granting a premium to the exports affected. In connection with an expansion of the scope and an increase in the rate of its export compensation scheme in July 1980, Kenya transferred the adminis- tration and execution of the scheme from the Customs Department to the Central Bank, thereby creating a multiple currency practice for eligible export receipts. The Lao People's Democratic Republic raised the premium on foreign exchange purchased from tourists and embassies and on inward transfers from 20 per cent to 40 per cent in March 1980. 6. Bilateral Payments Arrangements Bilaterism in payments involving Fund members, as measured by the number of active bilateral pay- ments arrangements between members and between members and nonmembers, continued its long-term decline in the period under review. While no new agreements involving Fund members were concluded, 13 such agreements were terminated. In preparation for its accession to EC membership in 1981, Greece abolished its remaining eight agreements by Decem- ber 31, 1980. The four agreements terminated among Fund members were Egypt-People's Demo- cratic Republic of Yemen, Greece-People's Republic ,of China, Greece-Romania, and Equatorial Guinea- Spain. The last agreement, which had long been inoperative, expired. Thus, on the basis of Fund membership at the end of 1979, the total number of operative agreements among Fund members would have decreased from about 27 to about 25 by early 1981. However, this number rises to about 42 af ter the reclassification as agreements among Fund mem- bers of 18 agreements (including the one terminated by Greece) maintained by the People's Republic of China with other Fund members that became neces- sary in light of the change in China's representation in the Fund. Nine bilateral payments arrangements maintained by members with nonmembers were terminated in 1980. Egypt and Pakistan abolished their agree- 25 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS ments with the German Democratic Republic, Nepal the one with Bulgaria, and Greece the ones with Albania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, the German Democratic Republic, Hungary, and Poland. With- out the reclassification of China's bilateral agree- ments, the total of members' agreements with nonmembers would have dropped from approxi- mately 121 to approximately 112. Adjusting both for China's 18 agreements with members and its 10 agreements with nonmembers, the total of mem- bers' agreements with nonmembers in early 1981 was approximately 104. Thus, total agreements involving members fell from approximately 148 at the start of 1980 to approximately 137 before the reclassification of China's agreements and to approxi- mately 146 after that reclassification. 7. Capital Flows Their high sensitivity to interest rate and liquidity changes in major financial markets once again made banks the main focus of measures to influence capital flows. In the major industrial countries such action, more than in previous years, was motivated by balance of payments concerns rather than by domestic liquidity objectives. The weakening of the current account positions of the Federal Republic of Germany, Japan, and Switzerland led to the progres- sive dismantling of the remaining barriers to capital inflows in those countries and, in a few instances, to measures designed to restrain capital outflows. In the case of the Federal Republic of Germany, these measures were supplemented by substantial direct borrowing from surplus countries. Many developing countries took additional steps to encourage inflows of foreign capital, while some of them relaxed exist- ing restrictions on capital outflows. Only a few developing countries introduced restrictive measures, due mainly to balance of payments pressures. In the Federal Republic of Germany, the banks agreed with the Bundesbank in February 1980 not to place borrowers' notes with maturities of five years or less abroad, while notes already held by banks could be placed abroad only if the remaining time to ma tur i ty exceeded four years. However, in March and November 1980 these maturity limits were gradually reduced to one year. In addition, the gentlemen's agreement whereby the banks undertook not to place deutsche mark-denominated bonds abroad through their foreign subsidiaries was recon- firmed. Effective February 1, 1980 the credit institu- tions were required by the Federal Banking Supervisory Office to include their open positions in gold, silver, and platinum in the calculation of their 26 daily open exchange positions. Also, from March 31, 1980, the credit institutions had to report monthly to the Bundesbank the nonresident claims and liabilities of their foreign branches and subsidiaries by currency and country. Minimum reserve require- ments on domestic and foreign liabilities were lowered across the board on three occasions: by 8 per cent in May 1980, by 10 per cent in September 1980, and by 7 per cent in February 1981. Supple- menting a decision by the Central Capital Market Committee in December to suspend new issues of deutsche mark-denominated bonds by nonresidents (see below), the Bundesbank concluded a gentle- men's agreement with the major credit institutions in December under which the banks undertook to restrain their long-term lending in deutsche mark to nonresidents (excluding commercial credits) until March 31, 1981. In March 1981 the Bundesbank instructed the banks that it would not seek an extension of the agreement but that banks would continue to have to refrain from placing abroad their own securities with variable interest rates (floating rate bonds) and issuing deposit certificates alien to German banking practices and denominated in deutsche mark. In March 1980, as a part of a new yen defense program, Japan announced a package of measures to facilitate the inflow of foreign funds, particularly through the banking system: (1) the raising of funds from abroad through interoffice free yen accounts by the authorized foreign exchange banks would be permitted on a more flexible basis; (2) free yen deposits held by foreign public institutions, including foreign central banks, would be exempted from the legal ceiling on interest rates; (3) medium-term and long-term impact loans (general purpose foreign currency loans to residents by banks in Japan) by Japanese banks could be permitted; (4) the private placement abroad by Japanese firms of yen bonds would be permitted, in some cases more freely. In April 1980 Japanese banks, which had been requested in October 1979 to slow down their medium-term and long-term foreign currency lend- ing abroad pending the development of their lending plans, were advised that such lending could be resumed to some extent, and in June loan-by-loan monitoring of such lending was eased. However, during April 1980 the Bank of Japan requested that the principal Japanese banks support the U.S. credit control measures by limiting annual net lending to U.S. residents from their offices located outside the United States to 6-9 per cent of their outstanding loans. In July deposit institutions were asked to ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAIN DEVELOPMENTS IN RESTRICTIVE PRACTICES exercise restraint in accepting foreign currency deposits resulting from the sale of foreign currency assets. With the implementation of the new Foreign Exchange and Foreign Trade Control Law on December 1, 1980 (see be low), the requirement for prior permission for foreign currency deposits by residents to exceed the equivalent of ¥ 3 million was eliminated. In January 1981, however, the reserve requirements on all foreign currency deposits were raised from a uniform 0.25 per cent to 0.5 per cent for time deposits and to 1.25 per cent for other types of deposits. In the United States, some important measures affecting the operations of foreign and domestic banks were introduced during the period under review: (1) in October 1980 the Federal Reserve Board issued final regulations implementing the provisions of the International Banking Act limiting the interstate banking activities of foreign banks in the United States; (2) from December that Act, and other recent legislation, subjected all deposit-taking institutions in the United States, domestic as well as foreign, to Federal reserve requirements; and (3) also in December 1980, the Federal Reserve Board proposed the creation of International Bank- ing Facilities in the United States that could make loans to non-U.S. residents and would be authorized to accept foreign deposits free from reserve require- ments and interest rate restrictions. Under a 1979 agreement with the People's Republic of China, the United States unblocked Chinese assets in the United States on January 31, 1980. In April 1980 the United States amended the November 1979 regula- tions on the freezing of Iranian assets by prohibiting certain payments and transfers by persons subject to the jurisdiction of the United States which involved the Government of Iran, its instrumentalities or con- trolled entities, enterprises controlled by Iran, or persons in Iran, and certain payments related to travel to and maintenance within Iran by most U.S. nationals. In January 1981, the United States directed the return to Iran of Iranian assets held at overseas offices of U.S. banks and revoked certain trade and financial sanctions and prohibitions against transactions involving Iran. Switzerland in February 1980 lifted the ban on the payment of interest on Swiss franc savings deposits of nonresidents; in addition, the National Bank resumed the payment of interest on time deposits of foreign central banks with a maturity of at least six months. At the same time, the limits on the forward sale of Swiss francs to foreigners were raised from 20 per cent to 40 per cent of the October 31, 1974 level for sales up to ten days and from 50 per cent to 80 per cent of that base date for sales over ten days. The limits on forward sales of Swiss francs to non- residents were lifted in March 1980 and interest payments were resumed on nonresident time deposits in Swiss francs with maturities of at least three months. The remaining ban on interest payments on nonresident sight and time deposits with maturities under three months was removed at the end of August. In June 1980 the National Bank decided to extend for one year its 1976 gentlemen's agreement with the Swiss Bankers' Association, whereby Swiss banks undertook to refra in from making deposits in Euro-Swiss francs or direct placements in Swiss francs in Switzerland for the account of and in the name of their branches or subsidiaries abroad. In September the National Bank relaxed the restrictions on capital exports, as follows : Domestic banks were allowed to participate freely in the granting of foreign currency-denominated loans and in the placement of notes in Swiss francs and other currencies for amounts not exceeding Sw F 10 million (or its counterpart in foreign currency). Trading of notes in Swiss francs among all domestic banks (not only among the issuing banks, as heretofore) and certain eligible investors was perm i t ted, subject to certain limitations. The placement of notes and debt certifi- cates with foreign banks and foreign monetary authorities was permitted, provided that the holders of such instruments undertook to keep them for their own account until maturity. The National Bank could require that the placement of notes with foreign monetary authorities be subject to agreement with the authorities concerned. The original maturity of loans should not be less than n ine years and that of notes, between three and eight years. Advance repay- ment would be subject to limitations. With regard to operations in foreign currencies, the National Bank reserved the right to introduce specific requirements, the general rule being that the banks could participate in foreign syndicates. Credits to nonresidents with multicurrency clauses would be allowed. Among other industrial countries, in July 1980 Australia eliminated the requirement that trading banks had to obtain prior approval f rom the Reserve Bank for large capital inflows before converting the foreign exchange involved into local currency, although exchange control approval would continue to be required for borrowing from abroad and for the transferr ing of shares in Australian companies to nonresidents. In Japan, the new Foreign Exchange and Foreign Trade Control Law entered into force on December 1, 1980 with the completion or revision of most of the govern- mental and ministerial ordinances associated with it. Although external transactions had been substantially liberalized in recent years, the basic principle had 28 remained one of prohibition of transactions unless expressly permitted. The new law reversed that principle, providing that transactions can be made freely unless expressly prohibited. In May foreign exchange proceeds other than those stemming from exports or their prefinancing could be deposited in accounts abroad. In March 1980, the South African Reserve Bank announced that it would grant approval more read- ily for the early repayment of certain loans, and in April it raised the forward premium of the rand against the U.S. dollar from 2.5 per cent to 12 per cent to stem the outflow of short-term capital result- ing from the large differential between domestic and foreign rates of interest. Since then the discounts have been adjusted regularly in accordance with changes in domestic and foreign short-term interest rates. In September 1980 Thailand extended for another year the exemption from the 10 per cent withholding tax on interest payments abroad for loans with an original maturity of more than 12 months. In the area of direct foreign investment, several developing countries introduced new measures to encourage direct investment. Argentina liberalized restrictions on direct investment in June 1980. Prior approval would no longer be required for investment up to certain limits in any of the country's stock markets. Moreover, approval was no longer required for investment in the public transportation service, and the limit on direct foreign investment without prior approval was raised substantially. In March MAIN DEVELOPMENTS IN REGIONAL ARRANGEMENTS privately had to be deposited in a commercial bank by September 1, 1980. The definition of gold coin for investment was expanded. In Thailand, the purchase, sale, or lending of gold on commodity futures exchanges was prohibited. Taxes on gold were imposed or reimposed by several countries. In January 1980 the Federal Republic of Germany applied value-added tax also to the sale of foreign gold coins which are legal tender. Mexico imposed a 40 per cent tax on excess profits from the sale of gold. Spain imposed a 30 per cent luxury tax on purchases of gold; however, gold purchased for industrial use was exempt from the new tax. In Switzerland, the retail sales tax of 5.6 per cent on sales of gold and gold coins to non- banks, which had been suspended in 1954, was reintroduced in January 1980. The Philippines reimposed the 4 per cent export tax and the 20 per cent premium duty on gold. Singapore announced that effective 1981 the tax on profits from offshore gold transactions would be reduced from 40 per cent to 10 per cent. The People's Bank of China raised the price at which it purchased gold from Y 3.04 per gram to Y 13.00 per gram in March 1980. A new range of fractional Krugerrands in denominations of l/2, 1A and Mo rand was offered for sale in South Africa. In February 1981 South Africa raised the limit on the domestic sale of Krugerrands from 150,000 ounces to 300,000 ounces per year. Other member countries issuing gold coins during the review period included Austria, Canada, Mexico, Panama, and the United Kingdom. In the cases of Austria and Mex- ico, the newly issued coins were not legal tender. IV. Main Developments in Regional Arrangements Most of the specific steps at fostering economic and financial cooperation during the period under review were centered on the EC and various coun- try groupings in Africa. The EC strengthened its bilateral agreements with nonmembers and was enlarged by the accession of Greece. On the other hand, the implementation of the second, institutional stage of the EMS was postponed sine die.2Q On January 1, 1981 Greece became the tenth member of the EC.27 An Agreement of Association between the EC and Greece took effect on Novem- ber 1, 1962 as the first step toward eventual member- 26 Developments relating to monetary cooperation within the EMS are described in Section II, above. 27 In addition to the European Economic Community, Greece acceded to the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM) and to the ECSC. ship for Greece. On June 12, 1975 the Greek authorities applied for full membership in the EC, and the negotiations were formally completed on May 28, 1979 when the Treaty of Accession was signed. The Treaty of Accession allows for a transi- tional period of up to five years. However, a special transitional period of seven years will apply to the free movement of workers and to the treatment of certain agricultural products. In connection with the EC membership, the Greek authorities estab- lished a foreign exchange market in Athens with effect from November 12, 1980. In conformity with the EC regulations, Greece terminated all remaining bilateral payments arrangements on December 31, 1980 and initiated the phased elimi- nation of advance import deposits on January 1, 1981. Restrictions on payments of interest and dividends were also abolished upon accession, despite the authorization for Greece to prohibit, until the end of 1983, the transfer of profits realized in the country by EC investors up to the end of 1985. In accordance with a resolution of the European Council in December 1980, the ECU replaced the European Unit of Account (EUA) as of January 1, 1981 in all financial instruments of the EC. The Supplementary Protocol to the Free Trade Agreement between the EC and Portugal, signed in Brussels on December 19, 1979, entered into force on January 1, 1980 for a period of two years. Throughout the year, detailed negotiations aimed at the accession of Portugal to the EC in 1983 took place. Disbursements of funds under the 1976 Financial Protocol between the EC and Portugal, which came into effect on November 1, 1978, were accelerated in January 1980 when it was decided to disburse the EUA 200 million available within a three-year period ending on October 31, 1981. In December 1980 an agreement was signed under which the EC would provide EUA 275 million of preaccession aid to Portugal to facilitate the integra- tion of the Portuguese economy with that of the EC. This aid will take the form both of investment loans from the European Investment Bank's own resources and of money drawn from the EC budget. The Gov- ernment of Portugal has taken a first step toward freeing the movement of capital by defining certain "priority sectors" for foreign investment. Negotiations also continued during the period with respect to the accession of Spain to the EC. The EC and Turkey on June 30, 1980 reached agreement on a set of decisions concerning the reactivation and fu r ther development of the Associ- ation Agreement. In the agricultural sector, the 31 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS Association Council decided to reduce the customs duties applicable to imports of Turkish products over a six-year period starting on January 1, 1981 and culminating in completely duty-free entry f rom January 1, 1987. In the social sector, the Associa- tion Council laid down the provisions to apply from December 1, 1980 to November 30, 1983 in respect of the free movement of workers. In the area of economic and technical cooperation, the main focus of attention will be the sectors of industry, energy, and training. Pending the entry into force of the four th Financial Protocol, Turkey will receive excep- tional aid in the form of grants totaling EUA 75 million. The four th Financial Protocol, due to enter into force on October 31, 1981, will provide a to tal amount of EUA 600 million over a five-year period. Under the Transitional Protocol between the EC and Cyprus, which was signed on February 7, 1980 and came into force on April 1, 1980, the first stage of the EC-Cyprus Association Agreement was initi- ally extended from December 31, 1979 to Decem- ber 31, 1980. The exploratory talks on transition to the second stage (establishment of a customs un ion) started on January 29, 1980. According to the terms of the Association Agreement, the customs union was to come into force in January 1981. How- ever, at a meeting on November 24, 1980 between the EC foreign ministers and a Cypriot delegation, it was agreed to extend the present agreement until the end of 1981. The first stage of the 1970 EC-Malta Association Agreement, which had been extended in 1977 un t il December 31, 1980, was extended for another six months to allow for fur ther negotiations. The EC and Yugoslavia signed a Cooperation Agreement and an Agreement on ECSC products in Brussels on May 6, 1980, in accordance with the Belgrade Declaration of December 2, 1976. The cooperation arrangements set up by the Agreement cover industry, science and technology, agriculture, energy, tourism, transport, the environment, fish- eries, and other areas. The provisions dealing with labor are based on similar agreements with the Maghreb countries (Algeria, Morocco, and Tunisia) and with Portugal. As regards financial cooperation, the Agreement provides for the financing of invest- ment projects valued at EUA 200 million under a five-year Financial Protocol. A fu r ther aim of the Agreement is to promote trade between the parties, due account being taken of their respective levels of development. Once the Agreement is in force, imports of Yugoslav industrial products will be free of customs duties and quantitative restrictions except for a number of sensitive products. This Agreement, 32 like those with other Mediterranean countries, accords tariff concessions on certain agricultural exports of Yugoslavia, while Yugloslavia grants the Community most-favored-nation treatment. The Interim Agreement between the EC and Yugoslavia on trade and commercial cooperation and the Interim Protocol for the advance implementation of financial cooperation entered into force on July 1, 1980. The Second Lome Convention covering the period 1980-85, which was signed on October 31, 1979 by the EC and 58 African, Caribbean, and Pacific (ACP) States,28 came into force on January 1, 1981 and will remain in force until February 28, 1985.29 The ACP States that have not ratified the Conven- tion will not be covered by the new provisions. On February 27, 1980 St. Vincent and the Grena- dines formally acceded to the Lome Convention, bringing the number of developing countries covered by the Convention to 60 (including Zimbabwe). Zimbabwe applied for accession to the Second Lome Convention on April 18, 1980. Without waiting for the actual membership proceedings to be completed, the EC has made provisions for advance application of the provisions governing trade (i.e., in practice, free access to the EC market for Zimbabwean prod- ucts) under an Interim Agreement. This Interim Agreement came into force on January 1, 1981. The Cooperation Agreement between the EC and the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN)30 of November 1979 was formally signed by the ministers on March 8, 1980. The Agreement, renewable every two years af ter the first five years, covers cooperation between ASEAN and the EC in trade, economic, and development matters. On June 6, 1980 the EC Commission opened negotiations with India for the conclusion of an agreement on commercial and economic cooperation to replace the Commercial Cooperation Agreement of 1974. A Framework Cooperation Agreement covering commercial and economic relations was signed on September 18, 1980 between the EC and Brazil. This five-year Agreement will replace the more limited Trade Agreement signed in December 1973. The first meeting at ministerial level between the EC and the Andean Group 31 was held in Brussels on May 5, 1980. The talks covered a range of political and economic issues. The first trade accord between the EC and a member country of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (CMEA) 32 was signed between the EC and Romania on July 28, 1980. The Agreement is a five-year Nonpreferential Pact that will cover about 85 per cent of the total trade between the two parties. An Agreement covering the establishment of a joint commission was also signed. Both Agreements came into effect on January 1, 1981. The accord follows contacts in the past that led to Romania's participation in the EC system of generalized pref- erences for developing countries. The Multilateral Free Trade Agreement between the member countries of the EFTA and Spain entered into force on May 1, 1980. On July 1, 1980 the EFTA countries reduced their import duties on most industrial products imported from Spain by 60 per cent and on some sensitive products by either 30 or 40 per cent, except for iron and steel products, which are not covered by the agreement. At the same time, Spain reduced its duties on some industrial products imported from the EFTA countries by 60 per cent' and on a large number of other industrial products by 25 per cent. The Agreement provides that any fu ture concessions on industrial products given by Spain to the EC will also be granted to the EFTA countries and that any such concessions given by the EC to Spain will likewise be granted by the EFTA countries. Thus, it prepares the way for the complete removal of industrial tariffs, which will be the consequence of the application to Spain, once it enters the EC, of the free trade agreements be- tween the EFTA countries and the EC. Special provi- sions govern the trade between Portugal and Spain. The separate bilateral agricultural trade agreements between Spain and Austria, Finland, Norway, Sweden, and Switzerland entered into force on May 1,1980. The fifteenth session of the UN Economic Com- mission for Africa (ECA) and the Sixth Meeting of the Conference of Ministers were held in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, during April 9-12, 1980. At the regional level, the Ministers recommended that efforts should be undertaken to: (1) establish sub- regional clearing and payments arrangements where they do not exist and strengthen existing institutions with a view to ultimately linking them with an Afri- can clearing and payments union; (2) establish an African Monetary Fund; and (3) set up an African mutual guarantee and solidarity fund. During the Second Extraordinary Assembly of the Heads of State and Government of the Organization of Afr ican Unity (OAU) held in Lagos, Nigeria, on April 28-29, 1980, it was decided to adopt a Plan of Action for the implementation of the strategy for the economic development of Africa. Within this comprehensive Plan, targets were set aiming at strengthening existing subregional payments and clearing arrangements and establishing payments arrangements in those subregions where they do not exist. It was also decided that member countries should embark on negotiations for linking up such arrangements with a view to forming an African Payments Union before the end of the present dec- ade. The Plan also aims at establishing an African Monetary Fund. An intergovernmental meeting on the proposal for a regional common market covering 18 Eastern and Southern African na t ions33 was held in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, from May 28 to June 7, 1980. The previous two negotiating sessions were held in Gaberone, Botswana, in January 1980 and in Luanda, Angola, in June 1979. The discussions led to the adoption of a d ra ft treaty and accompany- ing protocols that would set up a preferential trade area as a first step toward a regional common mar- ket. The fifth Summit Conference of the Economic Community of West African States (EcowAs)34 was held in Lome, Togo, on May 27-28, 1980. At the conference the Heads of State decided that, as part of the finalization of rules of origin, industrial enter- prises producing goods in the Community should have 20 per cent of their equity capital held by nationals of member states as from May 28, 1981, 35 per cent as from May 28, 1983, and 57 per cent as from May 28, 1989. Customs duties on industrial products originating in and traded within the Com- munity would begin to be eliminated by May 28, 1981 and the process would be completed by May 28, 1989. The elimination of nontariff barriers is to begin in all member states on May 28, 1981 and should be completed in May 1985. To compensate for the loss of revenue from tar iffs, it was decided that 20 per cent of contributions by the more advanced countries would be paid to the less advanced ones over an initial five-year period begin- ning immediately. One of the provisions of the Protocol is that ECOWAS citizens have the right to enter, reside, and establish business in any ECOWAS country. This right is to be accomplished in three stages, which should be completed during a maximum period of 15 years from the date the Protocol comes into effect. The Latin American Integration Association (LAIA) was founded on August 12, 1980 to super- sede the Latin American Free Trade Association (LAFTA)39 at the beginning of 1981. By creating LAIA the member countries abandoned the more ambitious multilateral tariff cutting framework of LAFTA in favor of a more modest institutional framework which would tailor tariff cuts to the relative strengths of its 11 member countries. Bilateral tariff cutting negotiations are encouraged under the new framework with the idea that the benefits will be extended to other members in future periodic negotiations. LAIA has three categories of members according to economic size: the large countries of Argentina, Brazil, and Mexico in one group; the intermediate group comprising Colombia, Chile, Peru, Uruguay, and Venezuela; and the group of small economies consisting of Bolivia, Ecuador, and Paraguay. Not for Redistribution ANNEX POLICY ON MULT IPLE CURRENCY PRACTICES The Executive Board has reviewed the Fund's policy with respect to multiple currency practices. The Fund shall be guided by the approach outlined in the conclu- sions set forth below. 1. Official action should not cause exchange rate spreads and cross rate quotations to d iffer unreasonably from those that arise from the normal commercial costs and risks of exchange transactions. (a) (i) Action by a member or its fiscal agencies that of itself gives rise to a spread of more than 2 per cent between buying and selling rates for spot exchange transactions between the member's currency and any other member's currency would be considered a multiple currency practice and would require the prior approval of the Fund. ( i i) An exchange spread that arises without official action would not give rise to a multiple currency practice. ( i i i) Deviations between the buy ing and selling rates for spot transactions and for other transactions would not be considered multiple currency practices if they represent the additional costs and exchange risks for these other transactions. ( b) Action by a member or its fiscal agencies which results in midpoint spot exchange rates of other mem- bers' currencies against its own currency in a relation- ship which d iffers by more than 1 per cent from the midpoint spot exchange rates for these currencies in their principal markets would give rise to a multiple currency practice. If the differentials of more than 1 per cent in these cross rates persist for more than one week, the resulting multiple currency practice would become subject to the approval of the Fund under Article VIII, Section 3. When difficulties are encountered in the interpretation and application of these criteria in specific cases, par- ticularly concerning the nature of official actions, the staff will present the relevant in fo rma t ion to the Execu- tive Board for its determination. 2. The policy of the Fund on the exercise of its approval jurisdiction over exchange measures subject to Article VIII, as set forth in paragraph 2 of Executive Board Decision No. 1034-(60/27), adopted June 1, 1960, remains broadly appropriate. In accordance with this policy, the Fund will be prepared to grant approval of mu l t ip le currency practices introduced or maintained for balance of payments reasons provided the member represents and the Fund is satisfied that the measures are temporary and are being applied while the member is endeavoring to eliminate its balance of payments problems, and provided they do not give the member an u n f a ir competitive advantage over other members or discriminate among members. The Fund will continue to be very re luc tant to grant approval for the main- tenance of broken cross exchange rates. 3. In accordance with the Fund's policy on complex mu l t ip le currency practices, as stated in Executive Board Decision No. 649 - (57 /33 ), adopted June 26, 1957, the Fund will not approve mu l t ip le currency practices under complex mu l t ip le rate systems unless the countries ma in ta in ing them are mak ing reasonable progress toward simplification and ultimate elimination of such systems, or are t ak ing measures or adopting programs which seem likely to result in such progress. 4. While u rg ing members to apply a l terna t ive policies not connected with the exchange system, the Fund w i ll be prepared to grant temporary approval of mu l t ip le currency practices introduced or m a i n t a i n ed pr inc ipa l ly for nonba lance of payments reasons, provided that such practices do not ma te r ia l ly impede the member's balance of paymen ts ad ju s tmen t, do not ha rm the interests of other members, and do not d iscr im ina te among members. 5. To assist the Executive Board in reaching a decision concern ing approval or nonapp roval of a mu l- tiple currency practice subject to approval under Arti- cle VIII, Section 3, the reasons unde r ly ing the practice and its effects w i ll be analyzed in reports on Article IV consultations or in other staff papers dealing with exchange systems. In all cases, consistent with the cycle of consultations under Article IV, approval will be granted for periods of approximately one year, in order to provide for a continual review by the Executive Board. Not for Redistribution Explanatory Note on Coverage of Individual Countries Part Two gives a detailed description of the exchange and trade system of individual member countries, includ- ing two nonmetropolitan territories. The exchange and trade system of one other country, which is not a member of the Fund, is also described. In general, the description relates to the exchange and trade systems as at the end of 1980, but in appropriate cases reference is made to significant developments that took place early in 1981. A standardized approach has been followed, under which the description of each system is broken down into similar headings, and the coverage for each coun- try includes a final section that lists chronologically the more significant changes dur ing 1980. The description of the restrictive system is not neces- sarily confined to those aspects involving exchange restrictions or exchange controls. As in previous Reports, questions of definition and ju r isd ic t ion have not been raised, and an attempt has been made to describe restrictive systems in their en t i re ty, except for the tar iff structure and, in most cases, direct taxes on exports and imports. Thus, the coverage extends to such features as import licensing, advance deposit requirements, import surcharges, travel taxes, export licensing, and export incentive schemes. Similarly, the section "Changes dur ing 1980" includes references to certain developments that may have a direct impact on international transactions but are not reflected in the body of the survey, such as ma jor revisions of import ta r i f fs or developments re la t ing to regional cooperation. The description given in the section Exchange Arrangement is in line with the no t if ica t ions of exchange arrangemen ts that member countries have fu rn i sh ed to the Fund under Article IV, Section 2(a). The struc- tu re of exchange markets is described, and the official exchange rate is given. The rates quoted are those effec- tive on December 31, 1980, unless stated otherwise. Under Administration of Control, some ind ica t ion is given of the authorities responsible for policy and adm in- istration of the controls and of the extent to wh ich the ir powers are delegated for work ing purposes. The section on Prescription of Currency describes the requirements a f fec t ing the selection of the cu r rency and method of settlement for transactions w i th o ther coun- tries. Where a country has concluded paymen ts agree- ments with other countries, the terms of these agree- ments o f ten lead to prescription of the currency for specified categories of payments to and f rom the countries concerned. The countries with which b i la te ral payments agreements are in force are listed either in the text or in a footnote. 38 Under Nonresident Accounts, a description is given of the manner in which the country treats accounts, if any, ma in ta ined in its currency by account holders who are not regarded as resident in that coun t ry, and the facil- ities and l im i ta t ions attached to such accounts. Where there is more than one type of nonresident account, the na tu re and operation of the various types are also described. In the section on Imports and Import Payments, import licensing requirements are described briefly, and details are given of other requirements imposed on pay- ments for impor ts and of any advance deposit require- ments. The term "open general license" indicates arrangemen ts whereby certain imports or other in terna- tional transac t ions are exempt f rom the restrictive application of licensing requirements, in contrast to an "individual license," which may be given e i ther free ly, or restrictively, according to adm in is t ra t ive decisions. Under Payments for Invisibles, the procedures for p e rm i t t ing paymen ts abroad for current transac t ions in inv is ib les are described briefly, together w i th any limita- tions on the export of fo re ign and domestic banknotes. Not for Redistribution AFGHANISTAN (Position on December 31, 1980) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Afghanistan is the Afghani. Until May 21, 1979 Afghanistan maintained a multiple exchange rate system with differing rates being quoted by Da Afghanistan Bank (the central bank ), the com- mercial banks, and by dealers in the money bazaar. On May 21, 1979 the exchange rate system was unified with a unitary rate fixed by Da Afghanistan Bank. This unitary rate is fixed in terms of U.S. dollars and is flexible. On December 31, 1980 Da Afghanistan Bank's buying and selling rates were A f 4 6 . 75 and A f47 .82, respectively, per US$1. These rates are applied by Da Afghanistan Bank and by all other banks to all transactions of both the Government and the private sector. Da Afghanistan Bank posts rates for deutsche mark, French francs, Pakistan rupees, pounds sterling, and Swiss francs, which reflect their value relative to the U.S. dollar in international markets and the local bazaar foreign exchange market (see below). Da Afghanistan Bank charges commissions ranging from 0.10 per cent to 0.375 per cent on exchange transactions. A number of transactions take place in the bazaar foreign exchange market, where the rates closely follow the unified rates. Administration of Control Foreign exchange transactions are controlled by the Government through Da Afghanistan Bank. The con- trol is facilitated by the existence of relatively large companies specializing in the export of such com- modities as karakul, cotton, wool, and carpets. However, these companies do not exercise a monopoly over the export of such commodities, with the exception that the export of cotton is reserved for four authorized companies. Prescription of Currency Settlements with countries with which Afghanistan has bilateral payments agreements1 must be made in the foreign currencies specified in the agreements. The proceeds from exports of karaku l, wool, and cotton to other countries must be obtained in convertible curren- cies. There are no other prescription of currency requirements. Imports and L ^port Payments Imports are not subject to license, but import trans- actions must be registered before orders are placed abroad. Imports of a few items (e.g., some drugs, liquor, arms, and ammun i t ion) are prohibited on grounds of public policy or for security reasons; in some instances, however, special permission to import these goods may be granted. The importation of certain other goods (e.g., a few textiles and selected nonessential 1 People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, and U.S.S.R. consumer goods) also is prohibited. There are no quantitative restrictions on other imports. Most bilateral agreements, however, specify quantities (and sometimes prices) for commodities to be traded. Most of the trade with bilateral agreement countries is carried out on a compensation basis, and usually both imports and exports are arranged by the same trader; imports against exports of cotton, natural gas, and wool are carried out by the Government or government agencies, or the proceeds of such exports are allocated for servicing of the Government's external debt. The present customs tar iff structure was promulgated in June 1974 and has since then been modified in the annual budgets. Actual tar iff rates, ad valorem and specific, vary considerably. Ad valorem duties usually range between 20 per cent and 35 per cent. Payments for imports through the bank ing system to payments agreement countries may usually be made only under letters of credit. Payments to other coun- tries may be made under letters of credit, against bills for collection, or against an under tak ing by the importer to import goods at least equivalent to the payment made through the bank ing system. Generally, a deposit of up to 40 per cent of the c.i.f. value is required by banks from private enterprises upon establishment of a letter of credit. Payments for Invisibles There is an exchange allocation f rom the banks for tourist travel abroad equivalent to US$2,000 a trip. In addition, tourists are permitted to purchase their tickets locally, including tickets for package tours. On application, foreign exchange is also allocated for busi- ness travel, as well as for medical treatment abroad, the amounts being determined by the appropriate authori- ties. The fee for a passport valid for one year is Af 20,000 for tourist travel, Af 5,000 for business travel, and Af 1,000 to Af 2,500 for other types of travel. Export by travelers of foreign currency notes up to US$2,000 or its equivalent is permitted only if the foreign exchange has been bought from the banking system. Travelers are not allowed to take out more than Af 1,000 in domestic banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports (other than gold) are not subject to license, but export transactions must be registered. Exports of a few commodities (e.g., opium and museum pieces) are prohibited. Otherwise, control is exercised only over exports to bilateral agreement countries (see section on Imports and Import Payments, above ). Proceeds f rom exports of karakul to all countries, including payments agreement countries, are received in convertible cur- rencies. Receipts from exports of karakul, wool, and 39 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution AFGHANISTAN cotton must be surrendered. Trav- elers entering Afghan is tan may br ing in any amount in Afghan banknotes. They may also bring in any amount in foreign currency but should declare it when entering the country if they intend to take out any residue when leaving the country.
